author: mcrypto16
content: Good day! I still have some misunderstanding about the liquidation technique. The explanation for the liquidation penalty states: "When liquidation occurs, liquidators pay off up to 50% of the outstanding loan amount on behalf of the borrower. In exchange, they can buy the collateral at a discount and keep the difference (liquidation penalty) as a bonus." Based on this definition, we can assume the following sequence of events: 1) the value of the collateral body decreases below the threshold. 2) The liquidator pays off half of the collateral for me, my collateral is reduced by half. 3) The liquidator buys out the remaining half of my collateral at a discount, I completely lose my collateral. 4) The liquidator receives a 7% bonus. Where am I wrong? Can you clearly describe the sequence of events during liquidation step by step? Thank you!

author: bslethereum
content: Welcome! If I have few general questions regarding lending stablecoins on AAVE can I ask them here?

author: bslethereum
content:
I'm planning to lend some USDC through AAVE dapp, either on Ethereum mainnet or L2 (probably Base) and have some questions regarding the process/withdrawals/profits etc. So far I did small lend of around 100USDC on Base, and based on that have some questions.
1. After commiting to lending stablecoin on AAVE, does all of that capital work for me? I mean I'm not sure about LTV section on the paige (which states: "The Maximum LTV ratio represents the maximum borrowing power of a specific collateral. For example, if a collateral has an LTV of 75%, the user can borrow up to 0.75 worth of ETH in the principal currency for every 1 ETH worth of collateral.") I guess this applies to borrowers, and 100% on my funds are earning interests?
2. After I put some USDC for lending I got ABASUSDC (on Base). I can see that amount of ABASUSDC is slowly increasing, so it is rebasing token, right? Can I sweep ABASUSDC to the USDC at 1:1 ratio?
3. Can I withdraw only part of my earnings, or do I have to close an entire position? Example: I lend 100 000USDC. After some time my portfolio increases to 100 500USDC. Can I withdraw 500USDC, so the rest of my saving still work for me?
4. In some black swan scenario, if USDC is deppeged from it's value, do lenders get punished for that?

author: weed42069
content:
1. All supplied tokens are earning interest.
- - LTV ratio is how much you can borrow if you use the token as collateral. It is similar to the Liquidation Threshold, which is the point at which your collateral gets sold if your borrow amount gets too high or your supply gets too low. 

2. Yes, your aToken balance is used to track your position and it is how you earn interest. You may send these tokens to other wallets

3. You can add, or withdraw as much or as little as you want. The remaining tokens will always earn interest.
4. Aave price Oracles will filter out anomalies, but if you use a token as collateral and it depeg, it can trigger a liquidation. If your tokens are not collateral, there is no risk of liquidation

author: 0xcosme
content: Hey! Interest rates on Aave are determined by the supply and demand ratio of the asset. When utilization is high, rates spike to incentivize more supply. This can be temporary and usually corrects once more assets are supplied to the protocol

author: 0xcosme
content: The utilization rate is high right now, which is why interest rates are rising, to encourage users who have taken out debt to repay and for new users to decide to provide liquidity to the pool.

author: imado.eth
content: i supplied 235$ USDC, and i got 250$ AAVEUSDC, why is that?

author: humagesa8634
content: The amount of aToken (e.g., aUSDC or aaveUSDC) you receive when supplying assets like USDC to Aave reflects the current exchange rate between the aToken and the underlying asset, which increases over time as interest accrues to the supplied assets. This means the 250 AAVEUSDC you received represents your 235 USDC deposit plus the yield generated by the protocol, which is factored into the aToken balance.

author: weed42069
content:
If you had some usdc already supplied, it's the interest you earned from that.

aTokens are only minted on chain when you interact with your position

author: hamburger8198
content: so uh  if the apy rate of USDC loan changes everyday, how does the system compute the rate of interest?

author: weed42069
content:
The interest rate is mathematically derived from the utilization rate.

When the liquidity pool is under utilized (under 90% of total supply is borrowed for most tokens) the interest will float towards slope1

Once the interest rate crosses the uOptimal (over 90% for most tokens), the interest rate will float towards slope2

The interest is calculated every single block and is adjusted in real time

author: weed42069
content:
Explaining to a 5-Year-Old:

Imagine you have a big jar of candy that you share with your friends. If only a few friends take candy, you charge them just a little bit for borrowing (this is like a small interest). But if almost all the candy is gone, you charge a lot more to borrow it (like a big interest) because you don't have much candy left.

Every time someone takes or returns candy, you check how much is left and adjust the borrowing price right away.


---

Explaining to a College Student:

Aave calculates interest rates based on the utilization rate of its liquidity pool.

Utilization Rate: The percentage of the total supply in the pool that is currently borrowed.

If less than 90% of the pool is borrowed (underutilized), the interest rate trends toward slope1, which is a lower rate.

If more than 90% is borrowed (overutilized), the interest rate shifts toward slope2, a steeper and higher rate. This incentivizes users to supply more liquidity or discourage further borrowing.



The interest rate is recalculated every block and adjusts dynamically in real time based on the latest utilization of the pool.

author: goodlyfeaddikts
content: My HF is 3.2 atm. Higher hf will incur less interest because of yield or no?

author: essah10
content: Nope high HF says nothing about the interest rates, a higher HF enhances the security of your borrowing position by lowering the risk of liquidation, it does not result in lower interest rates on your loans. Interest rates are influenced by market dynamics and the specific utilization rates of the assets you are borrowing.

author: weed42069
content:
Before using Aave, please review the [documentation](https://aave.com/docs) and ensure you understand how the platform functions.

When you are ready, you may connect your wallet to https://app.aave.com

You may choose any market (corresponding to a specific blockchain) to supply your tokens. Simply select "supply" and conduct the relevant transactions.

Interest is earned every block transaction, which is essentially in real time. Additonally, interest, for both supply and borrow positions, are added directly to the position's balance.

There are no required payments, and positions will be open perpetually until they are closed.

In the event the value of your borrowed tokens exceeds the Liquidation Threshold of your supplied tokens, you will be eligible for liquidation, in which up to 50% of your collateral will be sold to pay down your borrow position.

If you have any more questions regarding the Aave UI, feel free to let me know!

author: feribhellscream
content:
USDS is sitting at 99.4% Utilization Rate ðŸ‘€ 

What happens when USDS LP pull out? is this when staked Aave/GHO comes into action?

author: feribhellscream
content:
USDS is sitting at 99.4% Utilization Rate ðŸ‘€ 

What happens when USDS LP pull out? is this when staked Aave/GHO comes into action?

author: weed42069
content:
They can't withdraw if tokens aren't there.

I. E. If 100% utilized, they can't withdraw until someone supplies more or repays their borrow.

This token is borrowed in looping strategies, so it is highly leveraged against correlated collateral

author: weed42069
content: There'd be no use of the safety module here because this isn't bad debt

author: feribhellscream
content: oh okay, then I have a total missunderstanding of the safety module. Can I read up on the risks of safety module somewhere?

author: feribhellscream
content:
> The process of identifying and executing a slashing event is subject to an onchain Aave Governance proposal.

So there is no automated system? its just the Aave gov. proposing to use funds when in need?

author: feribhellscream
content:
> The process of identifying and executing a slashing event is subject to an onchain Aave Governance proposal.

So there is no automated system? its just the Aave gov. proposing to use funds when in need?

author: weed42069
content: At this time, it is not automated. With the developoments of [Umbrella](https://governance.aave.com/t/bgd-aave-safety-module-umbrella/18366/1) and [v4](https://governance.aave.com/t/temp-check-aave-protocol-v4-development-proposal/17541), there will be more automation process for slashing. The DAO recognizes this is an important and needed feature

author: feribhellscream
content: so in theory, a bad actor could propose to steal all staked assets? assuming there is enough votes?

author: weed42069
content:
I'd be uncomfortable saying so, given how decentralized Aave is, and how committed the community is to keeping governance in check. 

Additionally, Aave can be forked in the unlikely event of a governance takeover. 

But, to be fully objective, it is theoretically possible for Governance to be taken over and to make hostile votes. 

Again, I just want to emphasize Aave's level of decentralization. The DAO has been standing strong for nearly a decade now, and continues to grow in resilience. All DAO members and delegates hold eachother in-check, rigorously so. You can view the governance forums to see instances of proposals being fully vetted, no matter how reputable the creator is

author: feribhellscream

content: When borrowing the same asset, interest is typically the only risk for liquidation

author: weed42069
content:
Calculating Net Percentage Interest Paid When Collateral Earns Interest

**Formula:**

```Net Interest Paid (%) = Borrow Interest Rate (%) - (Collateral Interest Rate (%) Ã— Collateral Amount) / Borrowed Amount```

**Formula Breakdown:**

Borrow Interest Rate (%): The interest rate you pay on the borrowed amount.

Collateral Interest Rate (%): The interest rate you earn on the collateral you provide.

Collateral Amount: The total value of the asset you supply as collateral.

Borrowed Amount: The total value you borrow.


**Example Calculation:**

Collateral Supplied: 100 units of the asset

Collateral Interest Rate: 10%

Amount Borrowed: 75 units of the same asset

Borrow Interest Rate: 15%


Step-by-Step Calculation:

## 1. Calculate the Interest Earned on Collateral:

Collateral Interest Earned = Collateral Interest Rate (%) Ã— Collateral Amount
= 10% Ã— 100
= 1000%


## 2. Adjust for Borrowed Amount:

Adjusted Collateral Interest = 1000% / 75
â‰ˆ 13.33%


## 3. Calculate Net Interest Paid:

Net Interest Paid (%) = Borrow Interest Rate (%) - Adjusted Collateral Interest
= 15% - 13.33%
â‰ˆ 1.67%



**Result:**

Net Interest Paid: Approximately 1.67%

**General Formula:**

Net Interest Paid (%) = Borrow Interest Rate (%) - (Collateral Interest Rate (%) Ã— Collateral Amount) / Borrowed Amount

author: zoowee.
content:
Hello Aave community,

I have a question regarding the upcoming MiCA regulations in Europe, specifically concerning USDT. I currently have an outstanding USDT debt on Aave, and I'm concerned about the potential impact of USDT being banned in Europe from December 30, 2024.

Could someone please provide information on:

1. How will Aave handle existing USDT debts for European users after this date?
2. Are there plans to offer options for converting USDT debts to other MiCA-compliant stablecoins or EUR?
3. Will there be any changes to the risk parameters or availability of USDT on Aave leading up to or after the regulatory change?
4. What steps should users with USDT debts take to prepare for this transition?

Any guidance or information would be greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance for your help!
Thank's
Z.

content: So how long does it take to fix claim button for Arbitrum rewards?

author: 0xcosme
content:
An analysis of ARB claims associated with the ACI address revealed that some users remain eligible for rewards tied to Gauntlet's LM management. However, when these rewards are claimed, they are being misrouted to the ACI address instead of Gauntlet's intended destination. BGD is currently reviewing the analysis and plans to forward it to Gauntlet for further investigation and resolution.

The timeline for resolution depends on Gauntletâ€™s response time and the completion of the analytics review.  

The Safe holding the rewards can be viewed here: https://arbiscan.io/address/0xE79C65a313a1f4Ca5D1d15414E0c515056dA90b4

author: essah10
content:
Here an example

Ann deposits 12 ETH and borrows 6 ETH worth of USDC.
If Annâ€™s Health Factor drops below 1 her loan will be eligible for liquidation.
A liquidator can repay up to 50% of a single borrowed amount, that is 3 ETH worth of USDC.
In return, the liquidator can claim a single collateral which is ETH (5% bonus).
The liquidator claims 3 + 0.15 ETH for repaying 3 ETH worth of USDC

author: weed42069
content:
**How to Calculate Liquidation Price on Aave**

The liquidation price is the price of the collateral asset at which a borrower's health factor falls below 1, making their position eligible for liquidation.

### Key Concepts:
1. **Health Factor (HF):**
   ```
   HF = (Collateral Value Ã— LTV) / Debt Value
   ```
   - **Collateral Value:** Total value of your collateral in USD.
   - **LTV (Loan-to-Value):** Maximum loan-to-value ratio for the collateral asset (e.g., 80% means you can borrow up to 80% of the collateral's value).
   - **Debt Value:** Total value of your borrowed assets in USD.

2. **Liquidation Threshold (LT):**
   Each collateral asset has a **Liquidation Threshold**, which is lower than or equal to the LTV. If:
   ```
   Collateral Value Ã— LT < Debt Value
   ```
   the position becomes liquidatable.

3. **Liquidation Price:**
   The price at which the value of the collateral multiplied by the liquidation threshold equals the borrowed amount. For a single-collateral, single-debt scenario:
   ```
   Liquidation Price = Debt Value / (Collateral Amount Ã— LT)
   ```

---

### Steps to Calculate Liquidation Price:
1. **Identify the Variables:**
   - Collateral Amount: Amount of collateral supplied (e.g., 10 ETH).
   - Borrowed Amount: Total debt in USD.
   - Liquidation Threshold (LT): Percentage specific to the collateral asset (e.g., 85% for ETH).

2. **Use the Formula:**
   ```
   Liquidation Price = Debt Value / (Collateral Amount Ã— LT)
   ```

---

### Example:
- **Collateral:** 10 ETH  
- **Borrowed Debt:** $10,000  
- **Liquidation Threshold (LT):** 85% (0.85)  

```
Liquidation Price = 10,000 / (10 Ã— 0.85) = 10,000 / 8.5 = 1176.47 USD
```

If the price of ETH falls to $1176.47, the health factor will drop below 1, and the position will become liquidatable.

author: sleepby11
content: hello everyone, I have a question about Aave's algo

author: sleepby11
content: As we know, Aave targets an optimal utilization rate, typically between 80-95%. Interest Rate = Base Rate + (Utilization Rate * Slope 1)

author: sleepby11
content: If utilization exceeds the optimal point (typically 80-95%), Slope 2 kicks in: Interest Rate = Base Rate + (Optimal Utilization * Slope 1) + ((Utilization Rate - Optimal Utilization) * Slope 2)

author: sleepby11
content: My question is :When utilization increases, interest rates rise dynamically. Theoretically, as borrowers' interest rates increase dynamically, does this mean lenders' returns are continuously decreasing during this process? If lenders' returns decrease and attractiveness declines, does this mean fewer people will make deposits, leading to a reduction in TVL?

author: sleepby11
content: My question is :When utilization increases, interest rates rise dynamically. Theoretically, as borrowers' interest rates increase dynamically, does this mean lenders' returns are continuously decreasing during this process? If lenders' returns decrease and attractiveness declines, does this mean fewer people will make deposits, leading to a reduction in TVL?

author: artilugio
content:
Borrowers' and lenders' rates go up/down together.
If borrowers' rate is increasing then so is the lenders' rate, thereby incentivising lenders to deposit more (attractive interest rate).

author: sleepby11
content: What is the ratio of the fixed return. I mean how much of the fees go to lender and how much go to DAO, and how much is the revenue of the protocol?

author: weed42069

author: weed42069

author: weed42069
content: You can also view the utilization ratio : interest rate conversion at the bottom of each tokens dashboard

author: weed42069
content:
So think of a wallet as a literal wallet, but instead of holding credit cards, it holds your public and private keys

Everything that happens in DeFi happens on the blockchain, by interacting with a smart contract.

So, when you stake in your atomic wallet, on SUI, for example, you're not really staking in the wallet. The atomic wallet UI (User Interface) has "shortcuts", and on the back-end, you're actually staking into the SUI staking contract, as if you went to the SUI dApp and staked there manually. This kind of set up makes simple actions more user friendly, so users don't have to navigate dApps and go through all that hassle.

To stake on AAVE, you would go to app.aave.com and then go to the "staking" tab. From here you can connect your wallet, and then choose the staking option.

You will have to approve the staking contract in one transaction, and then the second transaction will be the actual staking transaction.

After staking AAVE, you will recieve stkAAVE tokens as a sort of receipt.

This process for staking AAVE is what the Atomic Wallet UI does for you in the background when you stake SUI

author: farida02977
content: What happens when someone canâ€™t pay their loans? Who claims it?

author: 0xcosme
content: Hey! Liquidation happens when a borrower's health factor drops below 1, meaning their collateral is insufficient to cover the borrowed amount. This can occur when the value of collateral decreases or the borrowing amount is increased. When a liquidation occurs, up to 50% of the borrower's debt is repaid by a liquidator. A liquidation fee is also levied against the borrower's collateral. Liquidations are permissionless, meaning any participant within the network can initiate the liquidation of an eligible borrow position.

author: farida02977
content: When someone initiates a liquidation, what do they gain?

author: 0xcosme
content: Liquidations are highly competitive, requiring a deep understanding of the protocol and technical proficiency. Liquidators closely monitor borrow positions, react swiftly to market changes, and prioritise liquidation transactions to be the first to execute the liquidation.

author: 0xcosme
content: You can read this for a more detailed information: https://aave.com/docs/developers/liquidations

author: albist
content:
Usually it means that the feed hardcodes 2 assets 1:1.
Do you have an example?

author: albist
content:
Hey,
MORPHO is the Morpho Protocol's governance token.

author: albist
content: This is a question only you can answer depending on your own criteria (:

author: albist
content: In this specific market it means the collateral (USD0++) and the loan asset (USDC) are hardcoded 1:1. So indeed it means that secondary market price fluctuation can no affect your position health ratio. But it doesn't mean that you can not get liquidated. You can get liquidation itf the interest acccrued to your position make your position unhealthy (the cost of your position -> Borrow APY).

author: albist
content: In other markets, the `hardcoded price` can only refer to a feed and not the loan asset and the collateral.

author: dogerton
content: that makes sense. But I am curious what made USD0++ qualify for hard coded 1:1

author: albist
content: It is how the oracle is built. The market creator chose an oracle that hardcoded UDS0++/USDC 1:1

author: khosbayar
content: when will support Base mainnet of morpho token on CEXs?

author: albist
content:
hey,
1. Morpho is an open, efficient, and resilient platform that allows anyone to earn yield and borrow assets. At the same time, developers or businesses can create markets, curate vaults, and build a range of applications on its flexible, permissionless infrastructure.
Morpho is more than a lending product, it is a lending and borrowing infrastructure on top of which people can build knowing that the base layer (Morpho) will never change as it is immutable.
2. It is not possible to deposit funds in the Spark DAI Vault as this Vault is dedicated solely to Maker's D3M.

author: albist
content: It is up to the CEX to choose to support the token on Base also.

author: albist
content:
Optimizers were  the first version of Morpho protocol but they are being deprecated by the DAO because too complicated to build on top of lending pools as Aave or Compound as they often change ([here](https://discord.com/channels/851206607324577823/901390815002230794/1311644350668603502) is why in details).

Morpho is the new protocol, immutable and permissionless lending and borrowing infrastructure. 
You can see what is Morpho [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/overview) and its benefits [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/benefits-of-morpho).

author: albist
content:
The performance fee works by taking a % of interest generated by the Vault. So the interests that are not taken by the performance fee go to the suppliers, creating the Supply APY -> the rate. More on performance fee [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/governance-&-fees).
I can only assume that Vaults not charging fees are bootsrapping liquidity and attracting users.

author: albist
content:
What do you mean by rug? Morpho vaults are fully non custodial. They never get ownership of the suppliers asset.
There is also a timelock feature for Vaults actions. You can read more about it [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/core-concepts#timelock).
Overall, you can read about the risk related to the use of Morpho Vaults [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/risk-documentation).

As for the Morpho revenue model, at the moment the Morpho protocol does not earn any revenue. But Morpho has a fee switch built into the protocol. Governance can enable a fee ranging from 0% to 25% of the total interest amount paid by borrowers for a given market.

author: albist

hey,
you can check all reallocations in a Vault by checking at the Vault page by scrollign down in the `Vault Reallocations` tab (see example attached).

author: albist
content: Timelocks preserve the noncustodial property of Morpho Vaults, ensuring users maintain control of the assets at any time and can withdraw them if they want to. You can read more about it [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/core-concepts#timelock).

author: albist
content:
Interest rates evolve according to the utilization rate of the market. Above 90% of utilization rate, interest rate will increase. Below 90% utilization rate, interest rate will decrease. The farther from the 90% utilization rate target, the faster interest rate will increase.
See here how the AdaptiveCurveIRM (IRM = Interest Rate Model) works: https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/irm#the-adaptivecurveirm

author: albist
content: Morpho is a remarkably simple protocol built in a singleton smart contract that groups every possible primitive market in the same place. This reduces gas consumption by 50% compared to existing lending platforms.

author: albist
content:
1. I don't necessary know of third party projects work (Maker, Ethena) and what they display. I can only answer for the Morpho side of things and how the protocol works.

2. **Morpho Markets** are simple, immutable lending markets containing 1 loan asset and 1 collateral asset.  Each market has its own interest rate. Markets can be combined to support any type of risk profile or use case. <- This is the base layer of Morpho, the lending and borrowing infrastructure, fully permissionless and immutable.
**Morpho Vaults** are curated lending vaults that can allocate deposits to any number of Morpho Markets. The rate of each vault depends on which Morpho Markets it allocates to. Each vault is customizable and has a different risk profile. <- This is a layer on top of the Morpho markets, allowing curators to provide a risk curation service.

if your talking about the proof of deposit token when you supply into a Morpho Vault then yes! It is an ERC20 token and you can transfer it to another wallet.
Note that rewards earned until the transfer is done will have to be claimed by the current address. Rewards will start accruing on the new address once the transfer is done.

author: zkpantani
content:
Got a question regarding depositing straight into markets, circumventing the vaults:
Does one accrue Morpho rewards this way?

author: zkpantani
content: I'd like to arb between the markets within the "Usual Boosted USDC" vault. The vault curators are doing such a disappointing job of balancing between the pools there.

author: albist
content:
You can earn rewards that are distributed at market level, not the ones that are distributed at vault level.
But we don't advise it because it requires knowledge and tooling to properly manage positions and curate risk.
Also by supplying directly to a market you may be earning in rate at first but you'd loose:
- liquidity reaggregation: a vault has less chance to become temporarily illiquid than a market.
- passive risk management: vault change market depending on oracle, LLTV and if there is a market downturn, etc.
- passive apy optimisation: vaults have allocators that constantly optimize apy (even though I understand you assess it as underoptimized)

So when I deposit some collateral on an isolated market (wstETH/WETH) and borrow, I will have to pay interest (fees) on the borrowing part and will not get any interest on the deposit, correct?

What's the point of depositing collateral, if you don't get any interest? I mean why would people use morpho and not Aave in that case?

Sorry if you have already answered these questions 100 times..

author: pistol_pete974
content:
Ok I think I get it, you could always want to just leverage your position.

And on wstETH/WETH pair, wstETH already includes an interest accrual from design.

I guess the pair where you have a negative 1D Borrow APY correspond to the pair where "lending would have a better rate than borrowing on Aave".

author: crotts
content:
Most borrowing actually happens against yield/interest generating assets such as wstETH and these collateral assets don't earn yield on Aave either.

On Morpho users have higher LLTVs so more borrowing power and therefore more efficient as well as better rates.

author: crotts
content: Negative 1D APY is usually when the APY of the incentives given to borrowers of a market are greater than the interest paid on their borrowed amount, meaning you're essentially getting paid to borrow.

author: albist
content:
Hey,
The reward calculation logic is block-based and the displayed amount is updated at different periods.
The displayed amount of MORPHO rewards corresponds to the amount earned up to 00:00:00 UTC.
For other rewards, the displayed amounts correspond to the amounts earned up to 30 minutes ago.

The rewards claim is working with an epoch system. At the moment an epoch lasts 2 weeks (goal is to make it shorter). When an epoch ends, rewards become available.
Let me know if you have more questions!

author: loopielu
content: could you please elaborate on the Pendle Linear discount oracle and its discount factor?

author: albist
content:
hello,
you can find discount information directly in the feed contract [here](https://etherscan.io/address/0x1c2375B4dA8ac4DF9ed05b73b4224123E5C6F237#readContract) with the `baseDiscountPerYear` and `getDiscount` funtions.

author: crotts
content: Essentially its takes a fixed price $1 and discounts this based on time to maturity of the PT. Further away from maturity the larger the discount.

content: As PT moves towards maturity the value of this collateral will converge to $1.

author: albist
content: Hey, this market are using discounted price feed, essentially its takes a fixed price $1 and discounts this based on time to maturity of the PT. Further away from maturity the larger the discount. As PT moves towards maturity the value of this collateral will converge to $1. You can find more details about the feeds at contract level. Is it clearer?

content: Actually, the closer to maturity, the closer to $1 it gets.

The oracle is what the lender, in this case Spark, think is best way to value the PT tokens.

author: dackblake
content: How am I able to start a $MORPHO market? The platform is permissionless and anyone is able to create a market correct?

author: albist
content:
Indeed, Morpho Markets and Morpho Vaults creation is permissionless, anyone can deploy a market or vault. However, setting the various immutable parameters for a well functioning market, or curate risk using a Morpho Vault, is no trivial task, and requires specific knowledge and appropriate tools.. You can see how to create a market in the doc [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/tutorials/market-creation).
Note that the Morpho interface does not display all markets, but only the one listed by established curators.

author: albist
content:
About the risk when you are a supplier in a Vault and the underlying markets collateral suffer a sudden loss, risk would be the bad debt one. Morpho has a liquidation mechanism to mitigate the risk of default and protect lendersâ€™ capital.
More on liquidation [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/liquidation).
Risk documentation available [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/risk-documentation).

author: albist
content:
No we don't as we are not risk curators.
Choosing the oracle, the proper LLTV with regard to the assets, etc. is done by the risk curators themselves.
They have their own strategies and assessment on  the parameters to create a market, which market they list, what % of allocation of a vault they allocate to the markets, etc.

author: yunusemrekaratas
content: I see that active TVL is present but token is released this month. Why is that?

author: albist
content:
The Vaults provide a risk curation service to suppliers by allocating supplied asset into underlying Morpho market, thus proposing a risk profile for the Vault.
Thr Vaukt curator will choose the market it lists and supplies on as well as the % of allocation in each market.
You can read more in the risk documentation [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/risk-documentation).
Let me know if you have further questions.

author: albist
content:
The new version of the Morpho protocol is live since the beginning of the year while the token has been transferable since a November 21.
Before transferability, Morpho users could earn the token but not transfer it.
More on that in the documentation [here](https://docs.morpho.org/governance/morpho-token/overview).

author: loopielu
content:
**Question concerning liquidation and borrow rate**
The borrow interest will only be due when repaying or will it be steadily deducted from my position? 
In other words: is my dept increasing over time because of the borrow rate and I am running the risk of being liquidated?
Szenario: I borrow DAI against my PT-sUSDe, my Health Factor is at 1,01. Will it change?

author: albist
content:
Hello,
the borrow rate is continuously compounding on your position. Your debt accrues overtime following the rate.
As a borrower you have to check the interest rate to be sure your position does not become unhealthy and eligible for liquidation.

hello!
As far as I know, the USD0++ token is only used as collateral to borrow other asset. I don't see any Vault allowing to supply USD0++ as a loan asset.

Oh alright! MORPHO was intended as reward token and not airdrop token

author: albist
content:
On MORPHO rewards, yes, it wasn't an airdrop but a rewards campaign voted by the Morpho DAO, and it is still ongoing. You can check the MORPHO rewards by hovering on the APY displayed on the Morpho interface.

About the Safe campaign:
- MORPHO rewards were distributed proportionally based on the average dollar amount deposited in a Morpho vault per block throughout the campaign. MORPHO rewards are claimable on the Morpho interface, not the Safe one.
- Safe points will be distributed using the same methodology.
More details on that [here](https://morpho.mirror.xyz/jt9uXS6hPJZiu1rcinLRqnoCNJQX37Kh_3hGgz8ScNw).

author: tuchisei
content:
Thanks, so no rewards for Lending and it seems that there are no available vaults for USD0++ 

Oh, so should I connect the wallet that's owning the Safe wallet to Morpho to see those rewards?

author: albist
content:
Yes, there are rewards for lending / supplying. But on Morpho the collateral and the loan asset are separated/different.
In your example of the USD0++/USDC market:
- USD0++ is the collateral, you don't earn a Supply APY nor MORPHO rewards by depositing collateral.
- USDC is the loan asset, the one you can supply, or borrow. If you supply USDC through a Vault on the [Earn page](https://app.morpho.org/?network=mainnet), you will get a Supply APY and most likely MORPHO rewards (to confirm checking the Net APY info). If you borrow USDC after depositing USD0++ as collateral, this borrow position will have a cost, but you might also be intitled to MOIRPHO rewards.
Let me know if unclear!

author: albist
content: And yes, to claim the Safe Campaign rewards, you will need to connect to the app with the Safe account that participated!

author: mr_onlyup
content: Hey, if I will supply in one of the vaults on ETH, the rewards claim and the withdrawal are liquid ? (can claim and withdraw any minute) ?

author: albist
content:
Hey,
yield coming from interest rates paid by borrowers is continuously accruing to you position and is withdrawable at any time provided there is enough liquidity.
At the moment additional rewards (MORPHO and others) are claimable every two weeks, current epoch started on December 3 and should end around December 17. When the epoch ends, rewards in the `Claimable in the future` column will become claimable.
Goal is to make epochs shorter.

author: mr_onlyup
content: And do u have any way to make sure that deposits won't be locked (because of low liquidity or other reasons, as I know other platforms have some protections against it)

author: albist
content:
When all the assets supplied into a Vault and allocated to underlying market have been borrowed, this is what is call [the temporary illiquidity risk](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/risk-documentation#liquidity-risk-for-lenders).
This risk is handle by the Interest Rate Model that increases rate when utilization is above 90%, more about it here: https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/irm
Let me know if you have more questions!

author: albist
content:
To be clear, the liquidity risk I mentioned above is temporary and has nothing to do with bad debt.
Iirc I think bad debt happened once during a lrt depeg (bad debt was the equivalent of 2 or 3 days of yield for users).
You can read more about it [here](https://forum.morpho.org/t/gauntlet-lrt-core-vault-market-update-4-24-2024-ezeth-price-volatility/578).

author: blabla7373
content: Hi there! WHere can I find information about epochs and hiw long do they last  the base chain?

author: albist
content: The Vaults curators can take a performance fee. The fee works by taking a % of interest generated by the Vault. The maximum performance fee is 50%. You can see the Vault's performance fee o nthe Vautl page.

author: albist
content:
It depends on the specific market and the oracle the market uses.
Lately lot of PT markets use a linear discount oracle meaning that at maturity, value of the PT is $1.
Has a borrower, you will need to repay your debt to withdraw your PT collateral. There is no 'force closed' position. Although such market will probably be less supplied after expiry, this will make the utilization rate increase as well as the borrow rate. You will have to take that into account and to repay to avoid liquidation if your position becomes unhealthy.

author: ssl7354
content: When shorter epoch? 2 weeks is way too long for today DeFi standards.

author: albist
content:
At the moment, the protocol nor the Morpho DAO take any revenue. Morpho has a fee switch built into the protocol. Governance can enable a fee ranging from 0% to 25% of the total interest amount paid by borrowers for a given market. But it has not been enabled yet.
As far as I know, fees represented by DefiLlama are interests paid by borrowers.

content: Clearly it is a shared feedback but there is no ETA at the moment for that.

author: albist

The epoch system allows for computain, offchain script and verification. You can read more about rewards and how it works in the documentation [here](https://docs.morpho.org/rewards/overview).
Epoch duration becoming shorter will happen with the automation of the several steps necessary to compute and verify rewards.

author: albist
content:
I think it is inappropriate to talk about scam.
1. Curators are independent third party that have their own strategy. Rebalancing between market and % of allocation in each market is their choice only. There are also cap they put into market to limit their market exposure.
2. As a borrower no one is forced to stay and you can repay at any time.
Utilization rate of the market can be decreased either by the supplier side or the borrowing side.
I understand your point but curators also have risk management procedure that drive their reallocations, no only rate even tho I expect from them that they are trying to give the best of both worlds.

author: albist
content:
Morpho has both!
**Morpho Markets** are simple, immutable lending markets containing 1 loan asset and 1 collateral asset.  Each market has its own interest rate. Markets can be combined to support any type of risk profile or use case.

**Morpho Vaults** are curated lending vaults that can allocate deposits to any number of Morpho Markets. The rate of each vault depends on which Morpho Markets it allocates to. Each vault is customizable and has a different risk profile.

author: albist
content:
hey there,
what you are sharing is a Morpho Vault. A Morpho Vault has no oracle, a vault allocates to underlying Morpho markets. The Morpho markets are the ones having an oracle.
**Morpho Markets** are simple, immutable lending markets containing 1 loan asset and 1 collateral asset.  Each market has its own interest rate, oracle, etc.
**Morpho Vaults** are curated lending vaults that can allocate deposits to any number of Morpho Markets. The rate of each vault depends on which Morpho Markets it allocates to. Each vault is customizable and has a different risk profile.

In your specific case linking to the [Spark DAI Vault](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0x73e65DBD630f90604062f6E02fAb9138e713edD9&network=mainnet), you can check in which markets it allocates by looking at the Vault Allocation Breakdown.

More on Morpho markets [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/overview).
More on Morpho Vaults [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/overview).

author: crotts
content:
Morpho is different from Aave in that it uses isolated lending markets. Vaults can list these different isolated markets which allows them to have unique risk profiles. At the same time borrowers can pay more equitable rates.

The downside is that the more markets listed by a vault, the more computation is required when withdrawing, hence the gas costs. 

Luckily Morpho is also deployed on Base where gas costs aren't a problem!

author: annasssdtat
content: if I supply rUSD (reservoir USD) what assets can I borrow?

author: albist
content:
hey there,
On Morpho, the Supply side and the Borrow side are separated.
On the supply side, on the [Earn page](https://app.morpho.org/), you can supply loan asset to a Vault in order to receive a passive supply APY and potential additional rewards. This supply can not be used as collateral to borrow. rUSD in your case.
On the borrow side, on the [Borrow page](https://app.morpho.org/), you can deposit some collateral to borrow loan assets. Note that collaterals on Morpho do not earn a Supply APY by default. Indeed, collateral assets are not lent out to borrowers. This alleviates the liquidity requirements for liquidations to function properly in current lending platforms and allows Morpho to offer higher capital utilization.
TL;DR you can not except if a market is created with the Vault asset as collateral (which is not in this case)

Ok found out!

author: roma_nft
content: Gm! Why is withdrawing funds to eth so expensive? x15-30 more expensive than a deposit of funds!

author: albist
content:
If you're withdrawing from a Vault with a lot of underlying markets (ie. asset pairs), gas fee can be high.

high markets listed vaults need to compute its total asset in order to perform the withdraw, and for this the vault need to update the interest on all the underlying markets.

content:
hey,
yes, on a market, the borrow APY can be broken down in:

- negative APY %, rewards earned on the side, claimable on an epoch basis, not autocompounding.
If. you have a specific market in mind I can confirm (:

Apart from smart contract and technical risk, is there a way to lose my supplied principal in relation to the underlying assets I am exposed to?

author: spade1323
content:
Apart from smart contract and technical risk, is there a way to lose my supplied principal in relation to the underlying assets I am exposed to? 

As in, if wbtc has an allocation of say 60% in a USDC vault, and wbtc goes down in price, does my principal lent in USDC also goes down?

author: albist
content:
Yes, as a supplier, the main risk I would see related to the collateral exposure of the Vault (related to underlying markets allocation) would be the Bad Debt one.
You can read more about it in the doc [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/risk-documentation#bad-debt-risk-for-lenders) and [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/advanced-concepts/bad-debt-realization).

author: jigglypuff0749
content: thanks, last question can i supply mbasis collateral even without borrowing usdc in mbasis/usdc market?

author: albist
content:
You can add collateral without actually taking a loan. But what would be the point?
Note that on Morpho Supply side and borrow side are separated, collateral assets are not lent out to borrowers. This alleviates the liquidity requirements for liquidations to function properly in current lending platforms and allows Morpho to offer higher capital utilization. 
So collateral does not earn a Supply APY by default.

author: albist
content:
You can add collateral without actually taking a loan. But what would be the point?
Note that on Morpho Supply side and borrow side are separated, collateral assets are not lent out to borrowers. This alleviates the liquidity requirements for liquidations to function properly in current lending platforms and allows Morpho to offer higher capital utilization. 
So collateral does not earn a Supply APY by default.

author: albist
content:
Morpho's vision is to become a backbone of Finance, a lending and borrowing infrastructure. Immutable, permissionless, on top of which anyone can build the product they want.
With the proper infrastructure, reducing costs, removing trust assumptions, it is the perfect public good to bring traditional finance onchain.
Spoiler here: https://x.com/MorphoLabs/status/1869065079720919335

author: albist
content:
hey,
first of all please ignore previous user proposing support via external link, it was a scammer and has been banned.

The reward calculation logic is block-based and the displayed amount is updated at different periods. The displayed amount of MORPHO rewards corresponds to the amount earned up to 00:00:00 UTC. For other rewards, the displayed amounts correspond to the amounts earned up to 30 minutes ago.

If your position is eligible to MORPHO rewards only, it will update at 00:00:00 UTC.
If you think there is an issue with other rewards not displaying, you can open a #ðŸ› â”‚support-ticket to share more specifics.

author: reycobos
content: Hi. I am wondering what's the point of borrowing on morpho? I mean, as I understand, the borrow APY is the rate we paid to borrow money. So if I borrow USDC using USD0++ as a collateral, I am paying 33.62%. Why am I going to do that? Do i miss something?

author: reycobos
content: Hi. I am wondering what's the point of borrowing on morpho? I mean, as I understand, the borrow APY is the rate we paid to borrow money. So if I borrow USDC using USD0++ as a collateral, I am paying 33.62%. Why am I going to do that? Do i miss something?

author: albist
content:
hey,
indeed, the Borrow APY (when positive) is the cost of your borrow position.
Your question is why would someone pay for overcollateralized loan I assume? It is not specific to Morpho but most lending venues.

I am not a borrower myself but more a passive supplier, but my understanding is that:
- You can use it to increase your exposure to an asset that has a yield (e.g wstETH) or with return speculations (by looping for instance). 
- You can use it for directional strategies like longing or shorting a token.
- Maybe you can do other stuff that I am not aware of.

My understanding is that simple users (like me), will simply supply to get a passive APY. More advance users will implement more structured strategies using Morpho.

Does it make sens?

author: albist
content:
hey,
indeed, the Borrow APY (when positive) is the cost of your borrow position.
Your question is why would someone pay for overcollateralized loan I assume? It is not specific to Morpho but most lending venues.

I am not a borrower myself but more a passive supplier, but my understanding is that:
- You can use it to increase your exposure to an asset that has a yield (e.g wstETH) or with return speculations (by looping for instance). 
- You can use it for directional strategies like longing or shorting a token.
- Maybe you can do other stuff that I am not aware of.

My understanding is that simple users (like me), will simply supply to get a passive APY. More advance users will implement more structured strategies using Morpho.

Does it make sens?

author: reycobos
content: Yes it makes sense, but what I see on the UI is not making sense.

author: reycobos
content: Compare to aave. You can supply different assets and then you can borrow different assets

author: reycobos
content: let's say you supply USDC for 10% APY and borrow USDT for 12%

author: reycobos
content: on morpho, on the borrow site, you can only supply one token and borrow just one token on that pool.

author: reycobos
content: and there is no supply APY, it shows only borrow APY

author: reycobos
content: So I don't get why someone would supply for example a stablecoins to get another stablecoin while paying 20 or 30% APY

author: albist
content:
Indeed, Morpho is openin a new way for lending. Let's address your points.

Aave or Compound are lending pools where you can supply asset and borrow asset, everything is in the same pool providing the flexibility you mention. Although, this kind of one size fit all is way less efficient than isolated lending markets.

If you're a supplier, you can choose a Vault that fits your risk profile (each vault can have a different exposition to collateral, LLTV, etc). So for instance if you supply USDC, you can choose low risk profile with mid APY or opt in for more exotic Vault and have a high APY.  Iirc, Vaults results in term of APY are at the top of what can be proposed.
So, for suppliers, actual choice in risk profile + good APY.

If you're a borrower, indeed, your collateral does not earn a supply APY, collateral assets are not lent out to borrowers. This alleviates the liquidity requirements for liquidations to function properly in current lending platforms and allows Morpho to offer higher capital utilization.
Although most of the time the collateral do not earn a high supply APY and Morpho high utilization rate can be a better advantage for borrowers.

On the specific case to supply a stablecoin to borrow another stablecoin, I don't. see exactly the added value here?

author: albist
content:
I invite you to check main Morpho benefits in the documentation [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/benefits-of-morpho) as well as what makes Morpho unique in these articles:
- [The Two Paths Ahead For DeFi: Decentralized Brokers vs. Protocols.](https://morpho.mirror.xyz/KCMBXBYPOE-aYvPuu5vSVzUozoO98QqZsYHvx5TYz5c)
- [The Metamorphosis DeFi Lending Needs](https://morpho.mirror.xyz/EzJu5-3zdzlqdwP8kwnYwVYZD2iONz5PF4ohe--VPyE)
- [Itâ€™s time to talk about DeFiâ€™s risk management problems.](https://morpho.mirror.xyz/F652srnxjv4qsIEHLUrDwOvrYgXU8p0io2cNogb2BJY)

They will explain it better than I do ^^

content: Hello, I have a question regarding USD0++ / USDC market https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0xb48bb53f0f2690c71e8813f2dc7ed6fca9ac4b0ace3faa37b4a8e5ece38fa1a2&network=mainnet. But for instance, in the sUSDe / DAI market, the sUSADe does some yield ?

author: albist
content:
When it mentions yield, it is related to a potential Supply API you would get from depositing collateral. Not the native yield of the asset.
Collateral assets are not lent out to borrowers. This alleviates the liquidity requirements for liquidations to function properly in current lending platforms and allows Morpho to offer higher capital utilization.

USD0++ / USDC --> disclaimer : https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0xb48bb53f0f2690c71e8813f2dc7ed6fca9ac4b0ace3faa37b4a8e5ece38fa1a2&network=mainnet (at the collateral level)

sUSDe / DAI --> no disclaimer : https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0x39d11026eae1c6ec02aa4c0910778664089cdd97c3fd23f68f7cd05e2e95af48&network=mainnet

content: The disclaimer is not very clear actually, because at first reading, I understand that "USD0++ won't generate yield because used as collateral"

author: albist
content:
disclaimer is only for the yield that could come from a Supply APY provided by the Morpho protocol.
The disclaimer does not take account for assets' native APY or any inventives / rewards provided by the assets issuers or third party projects.

author: lalateam
content: Hello, When I look into the oracle for the USD0++ market, the website shows the warming: Market is using a hardcoded oracle feed, What does it mean?

author: lalateam
content: Does it mean that USD0++ always keep 1 USD valued in morpho market even if De-pegging occurs in Curve or other market ?

author: albist
content:
Morpho is oracle agnostic (more on this [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/oracle-agnostic-pricing)), so each market can have a different oracle.
In the case of the market you shared, the [USD0++ / USDC (LLTV=86%)](https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0xb48bb53f0f2690c71e8813f2dc7ed6fca9ac4b0ace3faa37b4a8e5ece38fa1a2&network=mainnet), this market's oracle hardcodes USD0++ and USDC 1:1

author: lalateam
content: Will this hardcoded oracle be changed in the future ?

author: albist
content:
The oracle address is one of the parameters setup at market creation. This parameters are immutable. The oracler address can not be changed.
More on the Morpho markets' parameters [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/overview).

content: What's the difference between deposting USDC on Moonwell vs Morpho? Since it comes up on both sites as my position?

author: albist
content:
It only means that the available liquidity on the underlying markets is higher than what the Vault supplied in it. So all liquidity supply in a market can be retrieve by the Vault at any time.
e.g for this [Smokehouse USDC](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0xBEeFFF209270748ddd194831b3fa287a5386f5bC&network=mainnet) vault, allocated $7.47M to the [USD0USD0++ / USDC (LLTV=86%)](https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0x864c9b82eb066ae2c038ba763dfc0221001e62fc40925530056349633eb0a259&network=mainnet) but available liquidity in this market is $16M. So this vault can withdraw all its liquidity if it wanted to.

Is it clearer?

author: albist
content: If it uses the Morpho stack, only difference is the interface as far as I know.

author: albist
content:
There are 2 aspects impacting the MORPHO rewards:
- the total supply to market impacting the S_lim (S_lim is a threshold impacting MORPHO rewards rate)
- any Morpho DAO vote impacting the S_lim or other rewards factors
You can read more about it in this thread [here](https://forum.morpho.org/t/mip65-new-scalable-rewards-model/617#p-1104-proposed-new-approach-3).

author: mash2324
content:
This was the answer: Ah, noble seeker of knowledge, allow me to illuminate the intricacies of this financial conundrum with the clarity of a polished shield reflecting the sun's rays upon a battlefield! 

In the scenario you have presented, wherein the collateral, originally valued at 100,000 golden coins, has diminished to a mere 86,000 coins, we find ourselves in a precarious situation indeed. With the LLTV threshold established at 90%, the maximum allowable borrowing against the collateral would be approximately 88,888 coins. However, as you rightly noted, the debt stands at 80,000 coins, which is still within the permissible limits of the LLTV ratio.

When the value of your collateral plummets to 86,000 coins, the perilous balance of your borrowing becomes a matter of utmost urgency. The debt of 80,000 coins remains intact, yet the collateral's value is now insufficient to safely support that level of borrowing under the established LLTV constraints. 

In most lending protocols, this unfortunate situation would trigger a liquidation event, wherein the lender would take action to recover their funds. Typically, the protocol would seize enough collateral to cover the outstanding debt, which in this case is 80,000 coins. However, since the total collateral is now only 86,000 coins, they would take a significant portion of itâ€”potentially all of itâ€”leaving you with little to nothing in return.

Thus, to answer your query succinctly: all collateral may be taken to satisfy the debt, and you would be left with naught but the memory of what once was. A tragic fate, indeed, akin to a knight losing his prized steed in battle! Therefore, it is of paramount importance to monitor the value of your collateral diligently, much like a vigilant guardian watching over a treasure hoard, lest you find yourself bereft of both collateral and borrowed assets.

author: albist
content:
Hello,
MORPHO rewards are distributed at market level so direct suppliers are also eligible.
Through the Morpho interface it is not possible to supply directly to a market nor to track your position, and I don't think it is planned to be supported at the moment. The Morpho interface allows users to supply in Morpho vaults, that allocate assets to underlying Morpho markets.
Morpho is fully permissionless, anyone can interact with markets through other interfaces or directly at contract level as you did.
But we don't advise it because it requires knowledge and tooling to properly manage positions and curate risk.
Also by supplying directly to a market you may be earning in rate at first but you'd loose:
- liquidity reaggregation: a vault has less chance to become temporarily illiquid than a market.
- passive risk management: vault change market depending on oracle, LLTV and if there is a market downturn, etc.
- passive apy optimisation: vaults have allocators that constantly optimize apy

author: the1andonlydavid
content: Hey everyone. Happy Day After Christmas. Not a holiday but sounds like one. I am a new holder and really happy to have found this project. I bought a good chunk because I think this project will be one of the top ones this cycle.  I need some assistance with a few questions. How should I best position my tokens to gain some yield. Is there staking. I have never used vaults so if this is the strategy can you please direct me to some reading or videos that walk me through it? Thanks.

author: albist
content:
hello,
first of all ignore last user proposing you support in dm. It was a scammer and has been banned. Always stay in public channels and check users' role (Morpho Labs or Moderator) before interacting.
About the MORPHO token, there is no staking feature at the moment, only way to make it 'yield' would be to deposit liquidity in a pool, but that comes with impermanent loss risks.
About Morpho protocol, **Morpho Markets** are simple, immutable lending markets containing 1 loan asset and 1 collateral asset.  Each market has its own interest rate. Markets can be combined to support any type of risk profile or use case.
**Morpho Vaults** are curated lending vaults that can allocate deposits to any number of Morpho Markets. The rate of each vault depends on which Morpho Markets it allocates to. Each vault is customizable and has a different risk profile.

You can read more a bout it in the doc here: https://docs.morpho.org/

And you have a video tutorial on how to use the Morpho app in the #ðŸ“ºâ”‚guides channel

Let me know if you have more questions.

author: .arseven
content: Hey I got a question regarding LTV calculation. I'm depositing $6k worth of PT-LBTC to borrow cbBTC on Base. The max borrowed amount i can get is $4968. Front End show a warning that my borrowed position is near the max LTV of 86% and Liquidation LTV which is 91.5%. But as the number show, my LTV should be just 4968 / 6000 = 82.8%, still a far bit away from the 86% max LTV and quite less than the Liquidation LTV. Is this LTV calculation right? Why cant I borrow at the max LTV allowed of 86%?

author: albist
content: hello, no staking feature at the moment. Only way to get yield with MORPHO token afail if to provide liquidity in a pool which comes with impermanent loss risk.

author: albist
content:
hey,
The reward calculation logic is block-based and the displayed amount is updated at different periods. The displayed amount of MORPHO rewards corresponds to the amount earned up to 00:00:00 UTC. For other rewards, the displayed amounts correspond to the amounts earned up to 30 minutes ago.

author: albist
content: Not possible on Base due to low liquidity, you would need to brdge it to Solana.

author: albist
content:
Hello,
following user feedback, the `max` button has a 5% buffer between LTV and LLTV.
Since some user complained about the fact that the `max` button could actually allow you to borrow max (which could induce a liquidation shortly after if interest rates are high or in case of price fluctuation).
You can borrow more than the max allows by manually inputing the borrow amount.
But be careful about your health ratio. There are several warning message and and opt in button when you go over this buffer.

author: albist
content: hello, you can find Morpho contract in the documentation [here](https://docs.morpho.org/addresses).

author: albist
content:
Hello,
is it solved on your end?
If not please open a #ðŸ› â”‚support-ticket to share more specifics and I'll get back to you as soon as possible.

content: both uni and aerodrome cant find that addy and when I search morpho in aerodrome or descreener it gives me a different addy than in your docs, what am I missing?

author: albist
content:
LTV is computed directly from the oracle info and it does not us the $ value.

$ value in the interface uses other sources / feed than the oracle. 

only the oracle can impact your position. and the oracle does not impact the $ value displayed on the interface.

does it make sens?

author: albist
content:
did you check the pools in the MORPHO CoinGecko page?
MORPHO token addresses are the one in the doc. Nite that MORPHO token address is different on Ethereum and Base.

author: .arseven
content: no it does not at all make sense tbh. UI do show 2 different units (collateral PT-LBTC + borrowed cbBTC) and both has a $USD value. And when it come to LTV, calculation is using some other unit that does not show at all on the UI. So how do I know whether my position will get liquidated correctly?

author: albist
content:
You can know the health of your position with several info available on the interface and using the oracle (oracle being the source of truth for your position):
- LTV
- Health Factor
- Collateral Liq. price
- Collateral Price
- Price Variation to Liq.
If this info do not appear you can display it by clicking on "Edit properties".

author: hugow8452
content: hello I have a very trivial question but just want to be sure, mwETH is pegged 1:1 with ETH right ?

author: albist
content:
hey,
by mwETH you mean the proof of deposit token in a Vault?

author: albist
content:
Vault proof of deposit tokens are ERC20, so you can transfer it, and potentially trade it but afaik there is no such liquidity use.
On the 1:1 peg with the underlying asset (here ETH), proof of deposit token are not pegged 1:1
e.g if you deposit 1 ETH, it is normal that you have only 0.97 mwETH for instance because it represents your share in the vault, not the underlying asset itself. But worry not, if you withdraw from the Vault, your 0.97 mwETH will well gives you back 1 ETH + interests.

there are 2 different yield on a supply position:
- the rate: interest paid by borrowers and continuously autocompounding into your position. You supply position continously increases. Your share value will increase indeed.
- the additional rewards: MORPHO or others, those are claimable on the side, every 2 weeks for now.

content: hi, im researching morpho. through the docs, i think everyone can set vault and markets?

author: jonascyang
content: im trying to identify the difference between vault creator and market creator

author: albist
content:
hey,
indeed, vault creation and market creation is 100% permissionless, anyone can do it.

author: jonascyang
content: so the tailored risk profile for lender will be decided by the vault creator or owner, they are more like portfolio manager.

author: albist
content: From what I could observed, most of the time Vaults' creators also create market they will be using.  Choosing the market's parameters to fit the risk profile of their vault.

author: jonascyang
content: and if we focus on the market creator, they dont have any interest with everyone, they are also non-profitable

author: albist
content: Yes, the risk profile of a vault is curated by the curator or owner of a vault, by choosing which market to allocate to, and the % allocated to each market. Then by dynamically monitor and update the Vault exposure to curate the risk profile and optimize the APY.

author: albist
content: Confirmed, market creators do not receive a fee or any economic incentive to do so.

author: jonascyang
content: and , from my understanding,the main vault creator rn are pro firms?

author: albist
content:
It is not possible to have the exact same market with the exact [same parameters](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/overview) (creation tx would revert).
But indeed there can be market with same collateral and loan asset and different LLTV or Oracle. Depending on what the market creator think is best. 
Or just 2 or 3 markets with same parameters but different LLTV to provide different risk profiles.

author: albist
content: Indeed, at the moment, the Vaults displayed on the Morpho interface are curated by established curators with expertise in risk assessment.

author: albist
content:
No specific timeline has been communicated.
Usually, announcement is done when rewards become claimable.

author: albist
content:
hey,
Are you on the supply side, on the [Earn page](https://app.morpho.org/?network=mainnet) or on the Borrow side on the [Borrow page](https://app.morpho.org/borrow?network=mainnet)?
On the supply side for instance, the Net APY can be composed of two sources of yield:
- the rate: from interests paid by borrowers. Autocompounding continuously to your position
- additional rewards: MORPHO tokens or other token rewarded, claimable on the side every 2 weeks.
You can see the breakdown by hovering on the Net APY info (see picture attached).

On the Borrow side it is different, as the rate is not a source of yield but the cost of your borrow position, autocompounding to your debt. The rewards are a still a source of yield tho.

Let me know if not clear!

author: albist
content: Anytime, don't hesitate if you have more questons!

author: monkieboi12
content: Hey guys, im just stumbling across this now. Am i right in thinking some of morpho operates like a normal lending protocol? I currently have wbtc supplied in zerolend and am borrowing usdc against it long term. Can i do that hear? What chain is morpho on?

author: monkieboi12
content: Hey guys, im just stumbling across this now. Am i right in thinking some of morpho operates like a normal lending protocol? I currently have wbtc supplied in zerolend and am borrowing usdc against it long term. Can i do that hear? What chain is morpho on?

author: albist
content:
hey there and welcome to Morpho!
Morpho is a lending and borrowing protocol indeed! Morpho is deployed on Ethereum and base for now, but several new deployment will come soonâ„¢!
On the supply side you can choose a Vault to receive a passive supply APY on the [Earn page](https://app.morpho.org/?network=mainnet).
On the borrow side, you can choose a market. Morpho is different from other lending venues as it is composed of isolated lending market. Morpho Markets are simple, immutable lending markets containing 1 loan asset and 1 collateral asset.  Each market has its own interest rate. Markets can be combined to support any type of risk profile or use case. You can head over the [Borrow page](https://app.morpho.org/borrow?network=mainnet) and use the search bar to find the market that suits your need (e.g in the picture attached showing a market that allows to deposit WBTC as collateral to borrow USDC).

author: andrew1685364
content: Hi, if I deposit in earn vault, Iâ€™m eligible for liquidated collateral in the event of price crash is it ? I donâ€™t need to do anything and will get the collateral token automatically in the event of price crash right?

author: albist
content:
hey,
when a liquidation occur, the collateral goes to the liquidator who repays the debt (more about liquidations [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/liquidation)).
As a supplier in a Vault, you get a Supply APY from interest paid by borrowers and additional rewards like MORPHO token or other tokens (visible by hovering on the `Net APY` info).

author: dondaryl.eth
content:
hey Morpho Team, 

I need help on how did you calculate the APY for MORPHO rewards. Assuming that rewards on [ETH is not yet 2/3](https://forum.morpho.org/t/mip-86-morpho-reward-rate-changes/1205?u=morphoassociation)

e.g. `Steakhouse ETH` vault has `9,985 ETH` with TVL of `$35.69M`
UI is showing: Rate: `1.58%` while MORPHO: `4.42%`


0.000116 MORPHO per dollar per day * $35.69M TVL * 3.34 USD per Morpho = $13,827.73

TVL: `$35.69M`

I am getting `14.14% APR` but`4.42%` on the app.

author: albist
content:
Hey,
you can check the current amount of MORPHO token rewards per year per $ supplied or borrowed in the [rewards app](https://rewards-app.morpho.org/).
On the interface it is computed as shown in the documentation [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/tutorials/rates).
Let me know if you have additional questions.

author: wong1212
content: Thanks, so if I supply into today, I will see claimable rewards around 14th Jan? My first epoch period is shorter this time.

author: albist
content:
You will see your rewards accrue right away on the rewards tab (MORPHO token rewards are updated every day at 00:00:00 UTC and other rewards are updated every 30 min).
So you will see your rewards increasing in the `Claimable in the future` column.
And when the epoch ends on January the 14th, the rewards accrued will become claimable.

author: ssv.networktomoon
content:
Hello,

As a FLUID holder, itâ€™s important to highlight that Morpho operates as a governance-less protocol with immutable vaults, taking a â€œUniswap-likeâ€ approach. This model relies on creating the perception among investors that they might eventually activate a fee switch to generate revenue. This is unsurprising, given that both Morpho and Uniswap share a common lead investor, a16z.

The issue with both Uniswap and Morpho is that any fee switch would directly reduce LP revenue and in Morphoâ€™s case, it would also cut into the revenue of their risk curators, who currently claim 100% of the protocolâ€™s earnings. This dynamic creates a high risk of forks, as curators may fork the protocol to avoid sharing revenue with the platform.

Additionally, Morphoâ€™s business license makes their protocol open-source if a fee switch is activated 3, further exposing them to the risk of being forked by their primary risk curators. This makes the activation of a fee-switch extremely unlikely. As a result, thereâ€™s a low chance the Fluid DAO will see any yield from these tokens.

Moreover, Morpho is not a true DAO, and there is no significant avenue for participation in their governance, so the option of keeping these tokens for participating in governance makes little sense.

Given these considerations, and the fact that the Instadapp DAO already holds a large amount of FLUID tokens, we support the idea of building cash reserves by selling these tokens for USDC/GHO and using them to LP directly in FLUID to generate yield.

This strategy ensures that the DAO generates yield and provides funds that could be invaluable in the next bear market.

author: albist
content:
This person is right in the fact that Morpho is a governance-less protocol taking a uniswap approach. Morpho is immutable and permissionless. And this is what I personally like about it! It is what I had in mind when coming to crypto, having something actually removing the trusted third party.
His accusations are unsubstantiated and come from someone who sees Morpho as his enemy.
It is up to the Morpho DAO to decide when the fee switch is enabled. Not 'investors'. 
Fee switch can be tailored and apply to specific market. Also, this is not taking into account that Morpho can still provide better rate than other lending pool even with a fee switch enabled.
When Licence become public, I'm not sure it will be in people interest to fork Morpho ans start from scratch instead of just using it and enjoying the shared liquidity and network effect of the Morpho contract.

I think it's important to put into perspective the words of this person, whose main aim is to undermine Morpho.

author: albist
content:
There are two USD0++/USDC Morpho markets. Morpho Markets are simple, immutable lending markets containing 1 loan asset and 1 collateral asset.  Each market has its own interest rate. Markets can be combined to support any type of risk profile or use case.
There markets allow you to deposit USD0++ as collateral to borrow USDC.
You can read more about Morpho markets in the doc [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/overview).
And how to use the Morpho interface in the #ðŸ“ºâ”‚guides channel!
Let me know if you have additional questions!

author: albist
content:
indeed, Morpho markets are permissionless and anyone can borrow from.
there is a limited amount to borrow depending on the available liquidity.
when there is no more available liquidity, one has to wait liquidity to increase to borrow.
Morpho can not increase the available liquidity, it is up to suppliers to supply more and to Vaults to allocate more to a specific market.

author: albist

author: makaley
content: how can you use something if you limit its availability?

author: albist
content:
Morpho does not limit availability. The available liquidity is the consequence of the market (in a sens of offer and demand).
The Morpho protocol is limitless.

I understand you want to borrow on a specific market and there is not enough liquidity. But this is not Morpho that decide where the liquidity goes.
There are two aspects there:
- The suppliers: how much is supplied in Vaults
- The Vaults allocation: how much of this Vaults are allocated to the specific market
The later is up to the curators' choice, and they might allocate more as there is demand and if it fits their risk profile.

author: albist
albist
content:
There is no cap on the AdaptiveCurveIRM (Interest Rate Model currently used in Morpho markets). I think this user didn't fully understand how interest Rates are managed on Morpho. I'll make sure to point him the proper documentation.
TL;DR
Interest Rate are not capped, AdaptiveCurveIRM will make interest rates increase as long as utilization rate of the market is above 90%
More on that [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/irm).

author: gnomelabs
content: But why is the lending apr only 30%+ with a 100% fund utilization?

author: albist
content:
Depends on the history of the market interest rate. If the rate was low historically, it will take some time to get to high interest. But it will get there as utilization is above 90%. What do you think the interest should be at 100% utilization?
I personnally don't know. It is the market (in the broader meaning - supply and demand) that will determines it.

What you have to understand about the AdaptiveCurveIRM, is that it will adapt to what users are willing to pay to borrow / receive to supply -> the utilization rate.
- If borrowers think rate is too high, they will repay. Utilization will decrease. If still above 90%, interest rate will keep increasing but slower.
- If borrowers still think rate is too high, they will repay. Utilization will keep decreasing. If at 90%, interest rate will stop increasing. If below 90%, interest rate will start decreasing.
Same mecanic with supplier attracted by high interest rate.

Does it make sens?

author: albist
content:
Depends on the history of the market interest rate. If the rate was low historically, it will take some time to get to high interest. But it will get there as utilization is above 90%. What do you think the interest should be at 100% utilization?
I personnally don't know. It is the market (in the broader meaning - supply and demand) that will determines it.

What you have to understand about the AdaptiveCurveIRM, is that it will adapt to what users are willing to pay to borrow / receive to supply -> the utilization rate.
- If borrowers think rate is too high, they will repay. Utilization will decrease. If still above 90%, interest rate will keep increasing but slower.
- If borrowers still think rate is too high, they will repay. Utilization will keep decreasing. If at 90%, interest rate will stop increasing. If below 90%, interest rate will start decreasing.
Same mecanic with supplier attracted by high interest rate.

Does it make sens?

author: albist
content:
hey,
Morpho protocol is immutable. The protocol itself does not adapt.
However, there are immutable part like [the AdaptiveCurveIRM](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/irm) and [the Liquidation mechanism](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/liquidation) that are here to adapt to market (on the broader meaning) changes.
Outside of the protocol itself, curators can react to this kind of information and adjust by reallocating, modifying exposition to specific markets. 
I was not aware of any incomming changes.

Morpho markets are immutable. A few parameters are chosen at market's creation and can not be change: one collateral asset, one loan asset, a Liquidation Loan To Value (LLTV), an Interest Rate Model (IRM), and an oracle.

content:
This is the goal of the [Liquidation mechanism](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/liquidation) yes.
There could be circumstances in which the collateral's value for a position drops below the borrowed amount before liquidators can close the position, this is unlikely but can happen. author: albist
content:
The Native APY is the interest rate paid by borrowers.
The Net APY includes potential additional rewards and takes into account a potential performance fee from the Vault.
You can read more about Computing Rates in Morpho Vaults in the doc [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/tutorials/rates).

author: albist
content:
Morpho is oracle-agnostic (you can read more about this [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/oracle-agnostic-pricing)), anyone can create a market by specifying an address that returns the price for loan and collateral assets.
So erach market can have a different oracle.
You will find oracle information on each market page.
Example below for the [wstETH / USDC (LLTV=86%)](https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0xb323495f7e4148be5643a4ea4a8221eef163e4bccfdedc2a6f4696baacbc86cc&network=mainnet) market:

author: crotts
content:
Morpho never guarantees the safety of any market because there's always risk inolved e.g. bad debt risk, liquidity risk. 
More on that [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/risk-documentation/).

author: crotts
content:
Hard coded oracles means that liquidations cannot happen due to price fluctuations, but liquidations can still happen due to increase in accrued interest.
If the borrowers accrue interest to the point their value of loan > liquidation ltv then they will be liquidated.
It's up to the vault curators but they could decide to remove liquidity pushing borrow rates up to either force an borrowers to repay or be liquidated.

author: albist
content:
I think it is indeed important to separate the Morpho protocol, with the products built on top. 
Morpho is a permissionless system where curators are the one setting up both vaults and markets. The Morpho team does not manage vaults or markets. 

That said, Morpho Markets are isolated which prevents risk from one market impacting any others. In practice, that means only lenders in vaults that allocate to USD0++ markets have risk exposure to the depeg. Vaults that don't allocate to these markets have no impact. 
If a user does not wish to be exposed to USD0++ risk then they are free to withdraw from a vault that allocates to these markets.

author: albist
content:
Hello,
as answered here: https://discord.com/channels/851206607324577823/911288183138967553/1327209302758395927

As a supplier in a vault there is indeed a risk of bad debt.
You can read more about it here: https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/risk-documentation#bad-debt-risk-for-lenders

The Liquidation mechanism is there to mitigate this risk: https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/liquidation
