author: gilgameshod
content:
Hello everyone Gilga from MEV Cap,

We wanted to keep you posted, we also got the USD0++ redeem information late yesterday. We were not informed prior this decision by the Usual team, as the community it was a bit surprising for us too. 

Weâ€™re in touch with them and wait for more clarification regarding this redeem/burning system 1:1 USD0++ to USD0. In the mean time we prefer to limit the re-allocation to the hardcoded markets. 

That being said, we also deployed yesterday night a market called USD0++ naked where the USD0++ will be priced at the exchange rate which is currently $0.87 with a high LLTV. This has been done after we saw the statement from Usual

This would allow on the current borrowers to zap and move their position to this market without having to payback their debt and take a loss with the current depeg. 

Weâ€™ll then also work on re-deploying the same format for the PT and LP market, pricing USD0++ at the exchange rate which is $0.87

The LP markets will take a bit more time to be deployed due to the sensitivity of the price feed. 

We'll also share more detailed announcement once the new market is live.

author: albist
content:
Morpho Labs is not promoting curators. Morpho promotes how the Morpho infrastructure is used and can provide a tool to actually dencentralize lending and borrowing, remaining neutral and not emphasising one curator or another one.
Curators are independent, third-party risk experts who use their expertise to offer various Morpho Vaults.

The Morpho infrastructure is not intended to be opinionated nor to control chat curators are doing. Anyone can build on top of it. Maybe in a few months there will be hundreds of curators. Even if it was the goal, which is not, it is most likely actually not doable.

author: albist

author: albist
content:
When a borrower is liquidated, the borrower keep the loan asset he borrowed.
Its collateral is swapped by the liquidator to the loan asset to repay the debt.

author: albist
content:
The choice of a Vault depends on one risk profile and priorities.
There are several criteria to assess which Vault fits your risk profile and/or strategy:

- Who is the curator? His track record, risk expertise.
- What is the vault exposure in term of market (risk profile - some markets can be seen as riskier than other - collateral exposure, LLTV, Oracle, etc.)
- Is the curator taking a performance fee.
- The current and historical Net APY (rate + rewards) the vault is offering.

So it really depends on what you prioritize, APY, collateral exposure, etc.

You can read more on the technical side of the Vault in the doc [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/overview).

author: albist
content:
hey,
first of all, well played, be careful of scammers and support proposal in dm or via external link.

1. Interest rate will accrue continuously directly to your debt and you can repay at any time.
More on how Morpho work [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/overview) and how to use the Morpho interface in the #ðŸ“ºâ”‚guides channel.

2. Borrow APY can also change continuously depending on the utilization rate of the market.
More on Morpho interest rate model (IRM) [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/irm).

3. If you find a Vault to supply your asset you can yes.

Let me know if you have more questions.

author: albist
content:
as mentioned above, loan are not limited in time.
It is more the health ratio of your accont that matters.
Wether it is in 1 month, 1 year or 10 years. The important is that you repay before your account become unhealthy (by price fluctuation or interest rate accruing). You can either add collateral or repay partially or fully your loan to avoid that.

author: albist
content:
In a Vault you will see the Net APY, which is what suppliers earn.
I you go at market level (where the borrow happens), you will see the borrow APY and its history.
Each Morpho market is isolated and has its own interest rate model and borrow APY.

author: albist
content:
What do you mean by take care of?
There is always room to debate, but the main Morpho vision is to be a neutral infrastructure where anyone can build its own product. The Morphop stack is there to provide reliability and network effect. 1 smart contract, immutable and multiple time audited  bein the base layer for lending and borrowing.
I don't think app and projects would like that the stack they build on try to influence their vision or work. (My own 2c).
Now it is up to users to choose the product they want to use or not.

I guess the potentiel risk here for vault suppliers is not that available liquidity becomes 0 (I don't think so at least), but more that some bad debt happens (more on bad debt risk [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/risk-documentation#bad-debt-risk-for-lenders)).
It seems that currently underwater position are being liquidated by Usual and that no bad debt was realized.
It is just something that suppliers need to be aware of.

author: kang221_72699
content:
1. Repaying the Debt and Selling All Collateral
Total Collateral: $10,000 USD0++
Market Price: $0.93
Collateral Value at Market Price:
$10,000 Ã— $0.93 = $9,300

Debt Repayment: $8,600 (USDC)
Remaining Value:
$9,300 - $8,600 = $700

2. Letting Liquidation Happen and Selling the Remaining Collateral
Total amount required for liquidation (including penalty):
Debt + Penalty = $8,600 Ã— (1 + 4.38%)
= $8,976.68

Remaining Collateral After Liquidation: 1,023 USD0++
Market Price: $0.93
Collateral Value at Market Price:
1,023 Ã— $0.93 = $951

Strategy Comparison
Repaying the Debt and Selling All Collateral:
Remaining Value: $700

Letting Liquidation Happen and Selling the Remaining Collateral:
Remaining Value: $951
Conclusion
Letting liquidation happen is $951 - $700 = $251 more profitable.

This happens because, after liquidation, the remaining collateral can be sold at the higher market price ($0.93) rather than being accounted for at the nominal value ($1.00) during repayment.

Could it be advantageous for the borrower to be liquidated?

author: albist
content:
If by the bottom of the page you mean the chart it is because the chart shows the instant Borrow APY, compared the the 1D Borrow APY you see at the top (1D Borrow APY being the average of the last 24 hours).
You can display Borrow APY, 1D Borrow APY as well as 7D Borrow APY on the market page by clicking on `Edit properties`button:

author: albist
content:
Hello,
on Morpho there is no fee on deposit. Did you use Morpho or another interface like Moonwell?

author: albist
content:
On the Borrow side at the moment there is no additional fee than the interest paid to borrow: the borrow APY.
The borrow APY is the annual cost compounded continuously of borrowing the asset. The 1D Borrow APY is just the average of the last 24 hours.
To calculate the impact in daily cost you may want to use external tools to convert APY to daily / weekly cost (be careful of the tool you used + note that APY will fluctuate).

author: albist
content: A Borrow position has a cost, autocompounding to your loan (your debt increases over time). There is no additional fee at the moment.

author: albist
content: I guess the answer is that Contango does not provide the product you are looking for at the moment. You can check other apps in [the Morpho ecosystem page](https://app.morpho.org/ecosystem?network=mainnet).

author: dearearthlings
content: Hi is the** liquidation penalty** for the OLD pt usd0++ march 25 contract still on?

author: albist
content:
Hello,
The Liquidation Incentive Factor (LIF) is linked to the LLTV of a market and the later it is an immutable parameter of a Morpho market. So it can not be 'off' or modified.
More about Morpho markets parameters here: https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/overview
More about liquidation here: https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/liquidation

author: jonascyang
content: Based on my understanding, as a curator, they need to set market cap mult-times for different markets ?

author: albist
content:
So at market level there is no cap, no limit in supply, no limit in borrow.
But indeed, a curator can set supplyCap for specific markets. Meaning it gives a limit to the market exposure.
Vault 1 will set supply cap to underlying markets:
- Market A: 100M (<- the vault can not supply more than 100M to the market)
- Market B: 200M (<- the vault can not supply more than 200M to the market)

This supply caps can be modified according curators' strategy and exposure.

But you won't have this information at the market level. This Vault supplyCap informations will be available at Vault level but couldn't it on contract. Although you can retrieve it via the [Morpho API](https://docs.morpho.org/apis/morpho-vaults/#current-vault-market-allocations).

Let me know if not clear!

author: albist
content:
Hey,
Oracles are not at Vault level but at market level.
**Morpho Vaults** are curated lending vaults that can allocate deposits to any number of Morpho Markets. The rate of each vault depends on which Morpho Markets it allocates to. Each vault is customizable and has a different risk profile. 
**Morpho Markets** are simple, immutable lending markets containing 1 loan asset and 1 collateral asset.  Each market has its own interest rate. Markets can be combined to support any type of risk profile or use case. <- this is where you will find oracles into, at each market level.

In your case, you can check the Vault allocation in the Ionic Vault. I don't know which one you are referring to so I'll take the [Ionic Ecosystem WETH](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0x5A32099837D89E3a794a44fb131CBbAD41f87a8C&network=base) vault, you can scroll down to see it allocation into Morpho markets:

author: albist
content: Then, opening one of the markets, let's say the [cbETH / WETH (LLTV=96.5%)](https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0x6600aae6c56d242fa6ba68bd527aff1a146e77813074413186828fd3f1cdca91&network=base) for example, you can check oracles informations at the top of the page or by scrolling down:

content:
hey,
For the Vault reallocations table, it is possible that it does not take into account the initial allocation into the market. Only the movements after.

author: albist
content:
It depends, there are two things here. The vault theoretical exposition: the **supply caps**. It is the limit a vault can supply to a market.
- Within this supply cap (visible on the vault allocation page), the vault can reallocate instantaneously.
- If a vault wants to increase a supply cap of an already listed market (or add a market), this action is subject to [timelock](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/core-concepts#timelock).
You can check what actions are subject to timelock [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/tutorials/role-and-capabilities).

author: albist
content:
Actually you can not borrow if you supply on a MEV Capital Vault.
On Morpho, the Supply side and the Borrow side are separated.
- On the supply side, on the [Earn page](https://app.morpho.org/?network=base), you can supply loan asset to a Vault in order to receive a passive supply APY and potential additional rewards. This supply can not be used as collateral to borrow.
- On the borrow side, on the [Borrow page](https://app.morpho.org/borrow?network=base), you can deposit some collateral to borrow loan assets. Note that collaterals on Morpho do not earn a Supply APY by default. Indeed, collateral assets are not lent out to borrowers. This alleviates the liquidity requirements for liquidations to function properly in current lending platforms and allows Morpho to offer higher capital utilization.

Vaults share can be rehypothecated with new Morpho vaults v1.1 and it will allow in the futur to use Vault token as collateral (the equivalent of collateral providing a yield).

About the risk question, you can read more about that in [the risk documentation](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/risk-documentation).
Let me know if you have more questions!

author: albist
content: Discount linear adapter feed are feeds that give a linear increase to the value of a PT to get to 1 at maturity. So in this case, yes, the value of the PT will continuously increase until 1 at maturity and it is no exposed to second market price fluctuation.

author: albist
content:
hello,
at the moment there is not staking feature.
MORPHO is the governance token of the Morpho protocol, you can use it to vote on Morpho DAO proposals.
If you want to make your MORPHO 'earn', you can provide liquidity to a pool, but that comes with the risk of impermanent loss.
More on the MORPHO token [in the documentation here](https://docs.morpho.org/governance/morpho-token/overview).

author: texasblondie007
content:
I had originally posted this in the developers channel, maybe this is a better place for it because I didnâ€™t get a response from that channel:

Hi everyone. I may be posting this in the wrong place, but I think that experienced devs will have the best feedbackâ€¦ 

I, myself, am way beyond my scope of practice when it comes to computer science. But my husband, Meilough, has invested funds ($15K approximately, and has little return because none of the transactions have been executed as expected because of one malicious attack or another, leading to little or no return on his investments.) 
 
Still, Aaveâ€™s financial health and prosperity is important to me.

Now, letâ€™s consider the quantity of users who have lost some/most/all of their assets after interacting with the Aave platform. For the user affected by a malicious attack on their funds and/or wallet, whose â€œfaultâ€ it was is largely irrelevant. Damage was done, and they experienced financial loss. No one enjoys or is apathetic to losing money. And when it happens in Aaveâ€™s community, whether Aave is directly responsible for the attack or not, itâ€™s a bad look for Aave and it dirties our reputation.  

Here in the States, we have a tool called TrustPilot, a site used commonly by consumers across most industries that provides a â€œscaleâ€ based on data collected in regard to the trustworthiness of an organization. Guys- I was shocked to see a 2 out of 5 stars. Thatâ€™s like- low. Even â€œshittyâ€ businesses usually have a 3-3.5. Aave has a bad reputation in many regards. Iâ€™m aware that top-tier Aave reps try to combat it with the frequent posts in the governance forum warning users to be vigilant about watching for malicious playersâ€™ strategizing ways to attack or otherwise affect their transactions negatively.

author: texasblondie007
content: The bottom line is, the public image of the Aave brand should be of great importance to anyone looking to increase in Aaveâ€™s capital. Investors, both existing and potential, certainly keep an eye on it. A healthy reputation directly affects the comfortability of new and existing investors to keep their assets in Aaveâ€™s hands.

author: texasblondie007
content:
So hereâ€™s what Iâ€™m thinking: What if Aave got involved with the Marketing/R&D departments of some external wallet provider (such as Tangem. Meilough could help in this way, as heâ€™s already a partner with the company)? Could Aave use and build on the current technology to enhance user security somehow? And wouldnâ€™t some focus on this additional project, if successful, increase our overall ROI?

Based on a devâ€™s perspective, there are plenty of patterns where malicious occurrences have led to loss of user funds. We have tons of data already, regarding specific strategies used, all based on reports unfortunate Aave interactions. We could research these occurrences and find ways to use AI to identify them before the attack is carried out. Could we partner with a cold/external wallet using this intelligence?  By offering this as sort of a quid-pro-quo for an alliance with one of the external wallet retailers/systems they use?

author: 0xsantosa
content:
Dear AAVE Team,

My name is Santosa from IDNFT- the largest hub for Web3 education and adoption in Indonesia (idnft.id), and I am organizing an ambitious DeFi education initiative in 2025: The DeFi University Roadshow. This program aims to visit more than 10 universities across Indonesia, empowering students and communities with the knowledge and tools to engage with decentralized finance.

Over the last two years, we have successfully conducted university roadshows through our Web3 on Campus programs,  engaging more than 20 universities and over 6,000 participants. Our previous program partners include Binance Academy, Algorand, Tokocrypto, and others. Building on this success, we are now expanding our focus to DeFi in 2025.

Given AAVEâ€™s pivotal role as a leader in the DeFi space, we believe your participation would greatly enhance the programâ€™s impact. Our goal is to introduce students to real-world applications of DeFi and inspire them to explore innovative use cases.

We would love the opportunity to discuss this collaboration further and explore ways AAVE can be a part of this impactful program. Please let us know a convenient time for a call or meeting.

Thank you for considering this opportunity, and I look forward to your response.

Nb: Last year I joined the AAVE event Defi Renaissance in Bangkok, it was a great event.

author: benx009
content:
Hi, can anyone please explain what happened here:

I had 15080.97 in gho debt from before.  I just borrowed exactly 919.03 gho thinking it would bring my debt to an even $16k.  However now the UI says I owe $16,087.53.  Where did this extra $87.53 come from?  A couple of cents off would be fine but wasn't expecting this additional >$87 amount 

Did I just pay some APY upfront or something?  This is in aave core instance

author: benx009
content:
Hi, can anyone please explain what happened here:

I had 15080.97 in gho debt from before.  I just borrowed exactly 919.03 gho thinking it would bring my debt to an even $16k.  However now the UI says I owe $16,087.53.  Where did this extra $87.53 come from?  A couple of cents off would be fine but wasn't expecting this additional >$87 amount 

Did I just pay some APY upfront or something?  This is in aave core instance

author: 0xcosme
content: Hi, the extra $87.53 is likely accrued interest on your existing GHO debt. Aave recalculates your total debt, including interest, whenever you interact with the protocol (e.g., borrowing or repaying). This saves gas by not updating balances in real-time. The additional amount reflects the interest that accumulated on your previous $15,080.97 debt.

author: benx009
content:
Understood - thanks. I saw my gho balance slowly tick up and so assumed it was being updated in real-time - but admit it definitely didn't reflect the 15% apr I ought to be paying

Is this a lazy update behavior a recent change?  Because I have borrowed other tokens from aave in the past and relatively confident I saw those update in near real-time even without interacting with the protocol.

Or is this lazy update behavior something that is GHO-specific?

author: benx009
content:
Understood - thanks. I saw my gho balance slowly tick up and so assumed it was being updated in real-time - but admit it definitely didn't reflect the 15% apr I ought to be paying

Is this a lazy update behavior a recent change?  Because I have borrowed other tokens from aave in the past and relatively confident I saw those update in near real-time even without interacting with the protocol.

Or is this lazy update behavior something that is GHO-specific?

author: benx009
content:
Actually a great AI response haha.

Alright so this GHO-specific.  My personal take then is that this isn't a great customer experience, at least for us smaller users.  Maybe for whales they don't care.  But personally I'd rather pay a little extra gas to see my transparent real-time balance than to be "surprised" when I go to repay/borrow more.  Of course I wouldn't want to pay an exorbitant amount in gas and I'm not aware of the technical details there, but if it was just a little more I wouldn't mind.  Or at least even some off-chain integration that approximated how much interest has accrued on the debt would be great too.

Also, unless I missed something obvious, I didn't see any clear indicators in the UI that GHO debt updates lazily like this.  Gotta make that more transparent.  Now that I know about this behavior the shock factor is gone, but for other first-time GHO users in the future I could easily see this throwing them off too

author: weed42069
content:
Bot was wrong, interest works the same for all tokens, not just gho.

aTokens are only updated on the blockchain when you interact with your position. The UI, and the contracts calculate interest internally.

You can always see thr interest you've earned by subtracting current balance by deposit balance

author: albist
content:
hey,
first thing to understand on a market is that the collateral does not earn a supply APY by default. And that a market is a pair of collateral and loan asset.
That being said, for the [sUSDe / DAI (LLTV=86%)](https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0x39d11026eae1c6ec02aa4c0910778664089cdd97c3fd23f68f7cd05e2e95af48&network=mainnet) market, the collateral is sUSDe and the loan asset is DAI.

> why does it say borrow APY 19.08% and supply APY 17.45%
Supplying DAI to this market gave a 17.45% supply APY at the time.
Borrowing DAI from this market gave a cost of 19.08% Borrow APY at the time.

On the Historical Rates (see picture attached), changing the time interval only affects the chart. The number of borrow APY are the present ones.

author: albist
content: If you want to get the history of the Borrow APY of the market, you can display instant, 1D (average) Borrow APY or 7D (average) Borrow APY on the `Open a new position` tab by clicking on the Edit properties button:

author: 0xstalin
content:
Quick question, if the PerformanceFee is enabled on a Vault, would the fee be applied retroactively to all my earnings, or only to the earnings starting from the time when the fees are enabled?
- For example, if I have earned 1k USDC of rewards and the PerformanceFee was 0%, and, then, the performanceFee is set to 5%, would this 5% be applied to the 1k USDC I already earned while the Fee was 0%?

author: 0xstalin
content:
Quick question, if the PerformanceFee is enabled on a Vault, would the fee be applied retroactively to all my earnings, or only to the earnings starting from the time when the fees are enabled?
- For example, if I have earned 1k USDC of rewards and the PerformanceFee was 0%, and, then, the performanceFee is set to 5%, would this 5% be applied to the 1k USDC I already earned while the Fee was 0%?

author: albist
content:
hey,
only from the time the performance fee is set.
When no performance fee, the interest rate paid by borrowers are going directly to suppliers without "cut", making your position accrue.

author: 0xstalin
content: oohh, so, when the performance fee is set, from the interest paid by borrowers, the corresponding % based on the performance fee is automatically sent to the curator? Or they receive their cut until I claim the interests I earned?

author: 0xstalin
content: oohh, so, when the performance fee is set, from the interest paid by borrowers, the corresponding % based on the performance fee is automatically sent to the curator? Or they receive their cut until I claim the interests I earned?

author: albist
content:
yes it is automated, if a performance fee is set, part from interests paid by borrowers goes to suppliers, another part goes to the owner of the vault.
Note that the Net APY displayed at Vault level already takes account for the potential performance fee. Net APY is what the supplier gets.

author: mikem0844
content: Hi. A question about the uSUI pool. If I borrow stable coins against this token I pay negative interest? So I get rewarded in SUI tokens for borrowing against SUI?

author: mikem0844
content: Hi. A question about the uSUI pool. If I borrow stable coins against this token I pay negative interest? So I get rewarded in SUI tokens for borrowing against SUI?

author: albist
content:
hey, indeed, in the case of the [uSUI / USDC (LLTV=77%)](https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0x5d96564285fc3830f51fe495f88c29cc1232fbca61ca8b6edc25bff921efdef2&network=base) market, the rewards offset the cost of the position.
So basically you are being paid to borrow.
But note that the cost of your position (the rate) is continuously increasing your loan) while the rewards are claimable every two weeks on the side.

author: mikem0844
content: Ok, thanks. Yes 2.76%. So at morpho these pools do not work the same as most â€œnormalâ€ pools in that, when liquidity runs out, the rates do not rise exponentially, is that correct?

author: albist
content:
Currently on Morpho market, the interest rate is managed by an Interest Rate Model (IRM) called the AdaptiveCurveIRM.
This IRM adapt interest rate according to the utilization rate of the market. So yes, basically what you mean, if utilization rate of the market is above 90% interest rate will increase, resp. if below, interest rate will decrease.
More on how it works in the doc [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/irm#the-adaptivecurveirm).

author: albist
content:
Hey, there is no problem with the Vaults don't worry.
Indeed, [Moonwell Flagship EURC](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0xf24608E0CCb972b0b0f4A6446a0BBf58c701a026&network=base) and [Gauntlet EURC Core](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0x1c155be6bC51F2c37d472d4C2Eba7a637806e122&network=base) have currently temporarily no available liquidity.
What does it mean in practice, it means that all the EURC supplied in the underlying markets have been borrowed and that there is no EURC available to borrow further, or to withdraw by suppliers. This is the [Liquidity risk mentioned in the doc here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/risk-documentation#liquidity-risk-for-lenders). Let me reassure you, it is a temporary situation.
How it usually goes, all liquidity borrowed in the underlying markets make their utilization rate high, this causes the interest rate of such markets (and thus the Vault) to increase. With interest increasing, it will attract more suppliers, and/or push borrowers to repay their loan, thus improving the available liquidity.
Let me know if not clear!

author: albist

I don't know if a risk scoring should only depend on who is the curator. Each curator can provide several vault of the same loan asset but with different risk profiles, like Gauntlet is doing with its "Prime" and "Core" vault. Same curator, but two Vault with different risk profile.
But I fully understand this feedback, users need more neutral and objective information to be able to choose their Vault. This is something that is being looked into at the moment. I can no share any ETA tho.

indeed, iirc the first PT markets were hardcoded 1:1 to DAI.

author: 0xstalin
content: @albist | Morpho ðŸ¦‹ If I transfer from one account to another the tokens I get for supplying on a vault, the account where I transferred the tokens to will automatically continue to earn the MORPHO rewards?

author: 0xstalin
content: ooh, nvm, I've just seen the MORPHO rewards on the new address, looks like it needed to pass 24 hours

author: albist
content:
Yes, MORPHO rewards update every day at 00:00:00 UTC. This is why it may take some time to update.
Also note that the rewards already accrued in address A will not be transfered when you move your position from address A to address B.
As soon as transfer is done, rewards will stop accruing on address A and start accruing on address B. But rewards already accrued in address A stay in address A.

author: albist
content:
Hello,
The MORPHO rewards are provided by the Morpho DAO ans there is currently no end date. MORPHO rewards APY or distribution can be changed by DAO vote or following MORPHO price action.
There is no Vault fee or protocol fee when you deposit into a Vault. There can be a performance fee (more on that [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/governance-&-fees)) but that does not impact the gas fee.
Morpho is also deployed on base where gas fee is less of a problem!

author: ffxcord
content: will there be impermanent loss  in the usual boosted usdc vault?

author: albist
content:
hey,
impermanent loss is a risk related to liquidity pools.
Morpho Vaults are not liquidity pools but are lending vaults, curated lending vaults that can allocate deposits to any number of Morpho Markets. The rate of each vault depends on which Morpho Markets it allocates to. Each vault is customizable and has a different risk profile. Rhere is no impermanent loss risk.
You can check more about Morpho Vaults in the doc [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/overview), and the related risks [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/risk-documentation).

author: albist
content: yes it is due to underlying markets being more utilized (high demand it seems).

> To be honest, a 10% fee feels excessively high

> and Iâ€™m genuinely concerned that the existing curators could turn into vested interests
What do you mean by that exactly?

> limiting Morphoâ€™s flexibility.
Imho, Morpho flexibility can not be limited as its smart contract is fully immutable and permissionless, anyone can built on top any product.

> thereâ€™s a risk that Morpho could follow its competitors into monopolistic dynamics.
This is the point of Morpho, anyone can compete and it creates an open market. Encouraging competition and avoiding a monopolistic approach where you don"t have the choice to choose between different providers.

author: albist
content:
On your first point, I guess the point of having an open market is that there will always be someone to propose a better or cheaper service.
For instance there are a lot of 0% and 5% performance fee Vault at the moment.
You can check directly on the earn page. If the Performance fee column does not appear by default you can display it by clicking on "Edit properties".

author: albist
content:
On the second point, I guess this is the purpose of the Curator Onboarding Framework, decentralizing who is displayed on the Morpho interface or not.
I also guess that anyone can build its own interface, and product on top of Morpho, with its own interface. How I see this personally is that in the future there will be no need for a Morpho interface. Only the infrastructure / smart contract.

author: albist
content:
netApy  = average apy over markets excluding performance fees and including rewards
Net APY is already taking account for the performance fee of the Vault.

author: albist
content:
About rewards, you can read more about it [here](https://docs.morpho.org/rewards/overview).
TL;DR
There are rewards programs, rewarding actions on Morpho.
Third party can create a reaward program to incentivize Morpho.
It exists:
- Market rewards program -> to reward the borrow side, supply side, or both at market level
- Vault rewards program -> to reward the suppliers of a vault
- Uniform rewards model -> currently used by the Morpho DAO for MORPHo rewards at market level.

Rewards at market level on the supply side are for all suppliers, not only established vaults.

So I would say it is dependant on how the rewards program has been created!

author: la_distinction
content: sry, netApy and Net APY are different? netApy doesn't include performance fees and Net APY includes it?

author: albist
content: Sorry for the confustion. Both are the same. Performance fee is already taken account / removed from the Net APY (netApy).

author: dillon00052
content: Hi admin, quick question on the flow of the fund - once I deposited my money to a vault, where does my money go? Is it being locked in a smart contract or it goes to borrower / not in smart contract anymore?

author: dillon00052
content: Hi admin, quick question on the flow of the fund - once I deposited my money to a vault, where does my money go? Is it being locked in a smart contract or it goes to borrower / not in smart contract anymore?

author: dillon00052
content: And if Morpho has any security mechanism to protect lenders when hypothetically speaking the vaults got hacked and our money is gone

author: albist
content:
hey there!
First of all, Morpho Vault are non custodial, meaning you remain owner of your assets at all time.
When you deposit asset in a Vault, this assets are allocated to underlying Morpho markets (more about this [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/overview)), you receive a proof of deposit of assets into the vault which also represent a share of the Vault's assets.
All assets are held in the Morpho singleton smart contract.

It is indeed possible that all assets supplied into a Vault are borrowed, and thus the supplied assets are not in the contract anymore. But Morpho loans are overcollateralized so borrowers are incentivized to repay their debt to retrieve their collateral. This collateral is held in the Morpho singleton smart contract.

There is also a [liquidation mechanism](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/liquidation) to prevent potential bad debt.

author: dillon00052
content: Taking a read, thank you for your prompt response!!

author: dillon00052
content: I wouldnâ€™t worry too much about the bad debt. I worry about the collateral in the smart contract like a sweet pot for hackers. Why not put collateral in a cold wallet? Seems to me (regular retail users) more safe using cold wallet.

author: dillon00052
content: I wouldnâ€™t worry too much about the bad debt. I worry about the collateral in the smart contract like a sweet pot for hackers. Why not put collateral in a cold wallet? Seems to me (regular retail users) more safe using cold wallet.

author: dillon00052
content: so please tell me what would happen if (if possible at all), the collateral smart contract got hacked (in a million years)

author: albist
content:
All assets used on Morpho (collateral assets and loan assets when not borrowed) are held in the Morpho singleton smart contract. This contract is very simple (The protocol consists of only 650 lines of Solidity code), is immutable (Morpho is not upgradable. The protocol will run and behave the same way forever) and has been multiple time audited and formally verified (Morpho is known for its industry-leading security practices and follows a multi-faceted approach to security, see more on Morpho security framework [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/concepts/security/)).

In the unlikely case where the smart contract would be compromised, only solution for users would be to retrieve their asset from the protocol.

I am not sure how a cold wallet (managed by what / who?) would be more reliable than an immutable and multiple time audited smart contract. Morpho protocol goes back to crypto ethos where there is literally no trusted third party because it's all immutable and permissionless. But yes, you have to trust the technology and safety of the smart contract. This is why Morpho has industry leading practices.

Happy to develop if needed!

author: sorrymenow.eth
content: f(x) Protocol Morpho USDC Vault with 0 liquidity... borrow rate with 100% utilization rate is 5%? What is that? i can't withdraw my 200k USDC

author: albist
content:
there is no oracle error as far as I know.
The [f(x) Protocol USDC](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0x4F460bb11cf958606C69A963B4A17f9DaEEea8b6&network=mainnet) vault mainly supplies in the [arUSD / USDC (LLTV=86%)](https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0x6c65bb7104ae6fc1dc2cdc97fcb7df2a4747363e76135b32d9170b2520bb65eb&network=mainnet) market.
This market had historically a low Borrow APY. When the utilization rate went to 100%, the interest rate increased, going from 1% to 3.90% and now at 6.52%. As long as the utilization rate will stay above 90%, the interest rate will continue to increase. Until more suppliers come or borrowers repay. Thus improving the available liquidity.
You can read more on how Morpho interest rate model work in the [AdaptiveCurveIRM page](https://docs.morpho.org/).

author: albist
content:
Should be quicker than than. Rule of thumb is that at 100% utilization, rate double every  4 or 5 days.
I don't know what [arUSD / USDC (LLTV=86%)](https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0x6c65bb7104ae6fc1dc2cdc97fcb7df2a4747363e76135b32d9170b2520bb65eb&network=mainnet) borrowers are ready to pay tho. But Borrow rate should keep increasing fast as utilisation rate is at 100%

author: antonttc
content:
in liquidation, liquidators get the borrowers' lBTC, and repay their debt in wBTC

so as a supplier, your share always translated to wBTC, not lBTC

author: ludi1006
content: Whats generally considered the best USDC vault risk/reward wise

author: albist
content:
hard to say, each person will have its own assessment, the choice of a Vault depends on one risk profile and priorities.
There are several criteria to assess which Vault fits your risk profile and/or strategy:
- Who is the curator? His track record, risk expertise.
- What is the vault exposure in term of market (risk profile - some markets can be seen as riskier than other - collateral exposure, LLTV, Oracle, etc.)
- Is the curator taking a performance fee.
- The current and historical Net APY (rate + rewards) the vault is offering.
So it really depends on what you prioritize, APY, collateral exposure, etc.

author: kahunacapital
content: can someone explain to me how RE7 and others are able to take investment for their RWA vaults without doing KYC on investors?

author: kahunacapital
content: I understand it require coinbase attestation, but RWA requires accredited investor status, which I don't believe coinbase attestation provides?

author: albist
content:
Hello,
the verUSDC, used as loan asset in the [Steakhouse USDC RWA](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0xbEefc4aDBE58173FCa2C042097Fe33095E68C3D6&network=base) and [Re7 RWA](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0x6e37C95b43566E538D8C278eb69B00FC717a001b&network=base) vaults requires to have Coinbase attestations (`COUNTRY ATTESTATION` & `ACCOUNT ATTESTATION`). My understanding is that it acts as a KYC to use and supply verUSDC since Coinbase attestation is linked to a Coinbase account which is KYCed (could be wrong here but I think this is it).
Now if you want to borrow USDC, you also need to have this attestation, but depending on the collateral you are using (LTF, mTbill, USYC) there may be additional step to actually use the collateral.

Re7 itself is the curator of a non custodial vault, they never gain custody of the loan asset used in the vault and allocated to the underlying markets.

author: kahunacapital
content: how long does it take for eUSD rewards to show up on the rewards tab?

author: albist
content:
The reward calculation logic is block-based and the displayed amount is updated at different periods. The displayed amount of MORPHO rewards corresponds to the amount earned up to 00:00:00 UTC. For other rewards, the displayed amounts correspond to the amounts earned up to 30 minutes ago.
In your case, eUSD should appear ~30 minutes after if the amount is higher than 0.01
You can open a #ðŸ› â”‚support-ticket if any issue.

author: stickly3746
content: Why should I choose the moonwell cbBTC vault over Gauntlet?

author: albist
content:
Hey,
this is a choice that belongs to you.
The choice of a Vault depends on one risk profile and priorities.
There are several criteria to assess which Vault fits your risk profile and/or strategy:
- Who is the curator? His track record, risk expertise.
- What is the vault exposure in term of market (risk profile - some markets can be seen as riskier than other - collateral exposure, LLTV, Oracle, etc.)
- Is the curator taking a performance fee.
- The current and historical Net APY (rate + rewards) the vault is offering.

So it really depends on what you prioritize, APY, collateral exposure, etc.

We are working on making risks comparison more easy between vaults for users.

author: albist
content:
Hey,
you can check the breakdown of the Net APY in by hovering on the APY number:
Let's take the [Moonwell Flagship ETH](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0xa0E430870c4604CcfC7B38Ca7845B1FF653D0ff1&network=base) vault as example (it works the same for other vaults). Net APY displayed can be broken down in several sources as follow:
- **The rate:** interest rates paid by borrowers. Autocompounding continuously making your Supply position increase over time. (e.g around 0.36% at current rate)
- **The rewards**: (MORPHO and other token distributed by third parties). This rewards are claimable on the side every 2 weeks within an epoch system. (e.g around 4.16% in MORPHO + around 0.42% in WELL)
You can also see the underlying rate and rewards in the vault allocation frame.

author: .protocol_z
content: MEV Capital Usual USDC, Gauntlet USDC Core, and Smokehouse USDC all still indicate that depositors receive Resolv points. Is this accurate or will the UI be updated to only show 5x Resolv points for the Resolv USDC vaults by Gauntlet and Apostro?

author: albist
content:
Hello,
the rule provided by Resolv is:
- If a Vault supplies to Resolv collateral markets only (like. Resolv USDC or Apostro Resolv USDC) they get 5x Resolv points.
- If a Vault supplies to several collaterals markets (not only the Resolv ones, like Smokehouse USDC, Gauntlet USDC Core or MEV Capital Usual USDC), they get Resolv points.
Let me know if not clear or if infos are innacurate.

Still waiting an official reply from Ivan on this because itâ€™s really not clear on Resolvâ€™s side ðŸ˜†

author: tno2795
content:
**Problem Description**

During the use of Fluid, I have observed some issues and would like to hear the project teamâ€™s thoughts on these and potential solutions.

When performing operations in the liquidity pool (especially loops), we frequently encounter **insufficient liquidity** and **narrow liquidity ranges**, which result in highly volatile APY. This significantly impacts user experience and the system's efficiency.

 **Mechanism and Issues**
The **Smart Vault** and **Smart Debt** mechanisms in Fluid are based on inverse dual-asset ratios, as follows:  
1. **Collateral**: Represents real assets such as WBTC and cbBTC (e.g., 60% WBTC / 40% cbBTC).  
2. **Debt**: Corresponds to liabilities, with an inverse ratio of 40% WBTC / 60% cbBTC.

This design works well under normal market conditions. However, when there is significant trading activity for cbBTC or WBTC, causing slight price deviations, the following issues arise:

1. **Imbalance Between Collateral and Debt**  
   - For instance, if the collateral shifts to 90% WBTC and 10% cbBTC, while the debt shifts to a high percentage of cbBTC and very little WBTC, there is a significant imbalance.  
   - This creates extreme supply and demand imbalances for cbBTC.

2. **Severe APR Fluctuations**  
   - **Borrow and supply APR for cbBTC skyrocket**.  
   - Since most of the userâ€™s collateral is in WBTC while most of the borrowed asset is cbBTC, users face negative APY scenarios, with extreme cases reaching **-120% APY** (caused by extremely high borrow demand and limited supply, driving borrow APR upward).

---

#### **Potential Solutions**

Below are some preliminary suggestions for addressing this issue:

1. **Adjusting Liquidity Range**  
2. **Increasing Pool Depth**  
3. **Modifying Interest Rate Curve**  


**Questions for the Team**

- What is the teamâ€™s perspective on the **APY volatility issue** described above?  
- Are there other optimization directions or mechanism adjustments beyond the proposed solutions?  
- Are there plans to address these issues in future updates, such as adjusting liquidity ranges, interest rate models, or measures to attract more liquidity deployment?

I look forward to hearing your professional insights. Thank you!

to manage smart collateral and debt, swap operations in Fluid DEX are executed using two mirrored pools: one with "supply token1/borrow token2" and the second with "supply token2/borrow token1". author: xcolo
content:
I'm curious as to why there isn't a USDT-USDC/USDT-USDC SC/SD option available. This can be killer liquidity for USDT-USDC trades. Let's say if the LTV is 95%, liquidity threshold is 98%, having 6SC&5SD can be almost 11x effective.

On the protocol side, risk is hedged if liquidation goes well and no bad debt.

On the user side, better to manage the position carefully. If one asset loses its peg, this meaning the dollar value of SC decreases and the dollar value of SD increases, liquidation can be easily triggered.

author: smykjain
content: It'll mess up the markets of USDC/USDT and can make them really volatile. That's the reason we didn't increased caps on current sd USDC/USDT. Our market size needs to grow first to be able to make these use cases happen.

For example this transaction shows $22,748 on dex screener, but shows $85,345 on DeBank: https://debank.com/profile/0x205D10244C91586B4c36F642CCb573E07EbbFa8A/history?chain=eth&token=0x6f40d4a6237c257fff2db00fa0510deeecd303eb_INST

author: smykjain
content:
Yes, there's many different kind of losses. Losses from users side (like entry-exit price, if losses if user left during impermanent loss, leverage & deleveraging and so on) which is on users. Another is losses due to excessive rebalancing, the 2 majors factors that we mentioned are lack of CEX-DEX arbitragers (with Wintermute being the biggest one on this pool) & tight limits. Tight limits thing is resolved and CEX-DEX should be resolved in Jan.

While currently, the pool can be highly profitable but just because it's not integrated with CEX-DEX arbitrager it's resulting in the higher loss and hence why we are fine with Wintermute deal because we want to prioritize this integration.

$100k is an estimate and not the precise amount. The precise calculation will need to factor a lot of things and removing the cases which are user's fault which can take quite a bit of time.

author: xcolo
content: The mechanism of Fluid brings exceptionally high capital efficiency, which naturally comes with a higher risk of liquidation. Fluid ensures that the liquidation process well, and the rest depends on the user's own risk preferences, they do whatever they want

author: xcolo
content:
It's similar to a perps platform but more moderate.

On perps platforms, degens are addicted to leverage to gain exposure to spot positions, which makes the OI large and allows the platform to earn substantial revenue. Effective liquidation engines, insurance funds, and sometimes limited OI are common ways to manage risks.

On Fluid DEX, users can leverage up to 39x LP to earn fees, resulting in massive trading liquidity and significant revenue for Fluid. Risk management is handled through the liquidation mechanism, vault caps, and potentially an insurance fund.

People are still sleeping on Fluid, while HYPE is sitting at a 30B FDV.

author: xcolo
content:
Ok, let me write a new shill.

Uniswap and CEX Spot created the way to gain spot exposure.

Aave allows you to release liquidity while still holding the primary asset.

DEX/CEX perps help you leverage to get higher exposure for spot long/short positions according to your appetite.

Fluid DEX created the goal to get higher liquidity with less liquidity you actually have. It changes the way how liquidity works.

It remind me of the time when the perpetual contract was created, a 0 to 1 demand was created.

I have couple of questions regarding how fluid dex works under the hood, Iâ€™d appreciate some guidance ðŸ™
    1.    How are DEX pool position bound ranges determined?
    â€¢    For instance, in the ETH-USDC pool, the upper and lower bounds are Â±15%, while in the WSTETH-ETH pool, the ranges are much tighter at 0.01% and 0.04%, respectively. What factors influence these differences in bound ranges between pools?
    2.    Is it possible to alter the price bounds for a pool?

    â€¢    For example, WSTETH has been trading at a discount recently, which has caused the WSTETH-ETH pool to fall out of range. Can the price boundaries for this pool be adjusted?
    â€¢    If adjustment is possible, does it require deploying a new DEX pool instance with updated boundaries and migrating liquidity to the new pool with the revised price range?
    3.    Regarding the performance of the USDC-ETH pool:
    â€¢    The USDC-ETH pool has been performing well recently, gaining increasing market share in terms of volume compared to other DEXs. However, its price range is quite wide at Â±15%.

    â€¢    The USDC-ETH pool has been performing well recently, gaining increasing market share in terms of volume compared to other DEXs. However, its price range is quite wide at Â±15%.
    â€¢    How does this pool manage to maintain competitive pricing that attracts such significant volume despite the wide price range?

author: defi_made_here
content:
hi!

1. bound ranges are determined by governance, meaning that they are set up when the pools is created. in DEX v2, users will be able to select their own ranges for both SC and SD
2. range can be changed by the governance at any time. new pool is not required to be deployed. this is the main limitation of the dex v1 that ranges have to be manually updated rather than the users select their own ranges

author: defi_made_here
content: 3. if you check uni pool, it has most of liquidity in also ~ +/- 15%, so we can compete here despite having less liquidity

author: 0xmurathan
content:
For CLAMMs like Uniswap v3, liquidity outside the active tick is not utilized during trades. What really matters is the amount of liquidity within the active tick, as it dictates the price impact of the trade. Therefore, DEX aggregators choose routes based on price impact and transaction fee costs.

What I donâ€™t understand about Fluid DEX is how liquidity within the â€œactive tickâ€ is defined and how much liquidity is available for trading at any given time. For example, in the ETH-USDC pair with liquidity distributed across a Â±15% price range, how much of it is concentrated within the â€œactive tickâ€? Or perhaps the concepts of CLAMMs do not apply to Fluid DEX?

author: defi_made_here
content:
on eth-usdc position trading fees are autocompounded to your smart collateral and paying down your debt + you get fluid tokens on collateral and debt. Since the position is volatile, there is an IL, etc, your APY is just showing how much fees are getting on your position. Same on Uniswap, you can have whatever APY % but you might be unprofitabale due to IL

We will also introduce a separate dashboard where you can track your PnL rather than APY %.

author: defi_made_here
content: yes, it is should be like that if there is no IL / rebalancing losses

author: smykjain
content:
It's a bit weird to say that. The goal to build Fluid from the day one was the protocol should be 10x better than any other protocol in existence, protocol's growth should not be dependent on token but tokenomics should help boost protocol's growth.

If protocol is earning 10s or even 100s of millions, it's safe to assume the revenue will go into buyback. Now what to do with that buyback depends again on the governance, should governance distribute it or use it again for growth.

Fluid is the protocol which will grow even in bear market when other protocols will lose their token advantage. I'm more bullish then ever. We do not control the short term price of token but I cannot be less bullish on a long term token pricing.

About ve-tokenomics, if something interesting arise which just makes sense. I personally will be up for it but I won't be up for over complicating tokenomics and over gamifying things here.

Many protocols who have ve-tokenomics, their entire protocol is dependent on token. It's not the case with Fluid. Many of the biggest protocol does not have these kind of things which includes: UNI, AAVE, MKR/SKY, LDO, ETHFI.

author: lucyfer____
content:
i agree with you about the tech, and for that reason i think the price will pump as the bull market progresses. not even mentioning cex listing hype and improving protocol stats.

if the protocol is potentially earning millions a lot of that goes into the buyback. from there those proceeds go where gov directs. is there a dashboard which shows gov voting power/share of participants? ie how few voters are needed to push something through?

we've seen defi underperform all bull cycle, i think a part of the reasons are due to poor tokenomics design (sinks/burns/real yield/ve/inflation/tech risk/moat). all coins are memecoins imo, & it feels like the market is sniffing it out this cycle more than ever.

author: eip1559
content:
Is there a particular strategic reason why Fluid liquidity is so one-sided onchain. Backwards rationalising some reasons with varying degrees of confidence;
(1) Keep volatility high onchain for exchange arbs.
(2) Concentrate holder base, while hurting exits. Chinese Finger Trap.
(3) DAO owned liquidity starts one-sided but can be exited in WETH terms.

Has there been any deeper thought into this, as it's not very attractive to anyone with size or even insto perspective.

author: eip1559
content: Seems to be like placing the breaks on speculation (velocity of money). Which is counter intuitive in the event that your part of a rising tide, or at prodcut inflection.

author: eip1559
content: Greater confidence in throughput or token velocity from larger traders leads to a higher treasury value which essentially buys more growth.

author: defi_made_here
content: treasury has a lot of fluid which it can allocate but it does not have much eth it can allocate to the LP.

author: eip1559
content: While I understand a simplistic statement on treasury balance it does little to articulate the calibre or forward looking capability. Is there any strategy for building liquidity?

author: defi_made_here
content: as trading activities go through the pool, the liquidity is increasing there. the other way to handle it previous and future CEX listings with MM onboarding. And of course as the revenue grows, we will be buying back the token which will contribute to the liquidity

author: eip1559
content: This does limit the appetite for insto speculation in size until there is sufficient liquidity to meet their internal controls. May also limit the holder base to less sophisticated holders that are more likely to test the downside volatility of smaller liquidity. Which subsequently reduces the treasury at times when the 'gunpowder' would be beneficial.

author: defi_made_here
content:
I understand that everyone wants a cheap token with an infinite liquidity (which is provided by someone else as a charity) but this is the reality. I actually spoke with a fund which told me that bybit was very beneficial for them as they could use it to acquire tokens in a more efficient way.

That's smth what projects face in the early stages. As we mature, it should not be a problem at all

author: eip1559
defi_made_here
content: I didn't have intention to be rude or smth. What I am trying to say is that building/renting liquidity is expensive and at the moment it makes more sense to our affords into the other places. I am pretty sure, that liquidity won't be an issue within several months and I agree that currently it is not deep on the sell side

author: defi_made_here
content: Growing Fluid protocol market size is more important now than growing sell side liquidity.

author: eip1559
content:
The two are not mutually exclusive, in fact they are symbiotic. As you stated the homogeneity of the current treasury, limits resources for growth. The challenge I see is that in downside tests the skewed pool exacerbates negative associations. 

What you are saying makes sense. However even SNX had to harden the markers people look at.

author: justinmahone
content:
Does this accurately visualize how liquidations work on Fluid?

Users borrow in ticks, with each tick corresponding to a specific LTV ratio.
Similar to Uniswap V3's price ranges, where liquidity is distributed across ticks, in Fluid, borrowed amounts are distributed across LTV ticks.

First chart is user's debt position at 75% LTV, distributed across multiple ticks below the 75% threshold.

second chart show the collateral price (e.g., ETH) falls, the collateral-to-debt ratio (LTV) rises.
The user's position dynamically shifts into higher-risk ticks (closer to the liquidation threshold).

Lasst chart is when the LTV exceeds 92% (liquidation threshold):
The tick corresponding to >92% LTV is liquidated.
The collateral (ETH) in that tick is swapped into USDC (borrowed asset) to repay the debt.

author: justinmahone

second chart show the collateral price (e.g., ETH) falls, the collateral-to-debt ratio (LTV) rises.
The user's position dynamically shifts into higher-risk ticks (closer to the liquidation threshold).

Lasst chart is when the LTV exceeds 92% (liquidation threshold):

author: smykjain
content:
@JLtt currently all the markets are really tight so we have active rebalancing only on Fluid & Spark to Aave v3 as of now as Lite naturally is not managing anything on Aave v3 (due to weETH) but Aave v3 is the most liquid market.

Aave v3 as of now is dead end.

author: gitegite
content:
Hey you will see the difference once you withdraw them
the value should be pretty moderate as the rate was ~4%, so also depends on your amount

feel free to open a ticket on #ðŸŽŸ-tickets and we will double check it for you

author: 0xjltt
content:
Yeah it's very dangerous right now, all lending protocols are close to or above u-opt...
But I'm wondering, for example currently the AaveV3 main instance is/was at 8% borrow rates again, but the lite vault borrowed another ~1.5k ETH there 40 mins ago. (Can also see you guys did some deleverage before).
But just wondering why it's choosing AaveV3 with 8% rates instead of the AaveV3 Lido instance where currently around 12k ETH could be borrowed until u-opt.
Also on Spark there was ~8k ETH available at under u-opt rates (now around 5.5k right now). 
Is the Lite vault always choosing AaveV3 main instance preferentially because it's most liquid, even in moments where it's spiking and other markets have lower rates?

author: smykjain
content:
@JLtt the utilization on all protocols is to the kink and Lido's direct withdrawals are also taking some time. We are actively deleveraging the vault a bit.

From all protocols if kink is hit, we move the position to Aave v3 because it's the most liquid market and Lite is managing the smallest position there so impact on Lite's APR in minimum w.r.t to moving the assets to other protocol.

content: Hello, do you know if one or two transactions are necessary to make a deposit in Aave?

author: xerjos
content: If only the first one is executed and the process is not completed, is it appropriate to revoke said contract and start the entire process again?

author: 0xcosme
content: It is not necessary, the approval will be useful for when you want to finish the tx.

author: xerjos
content: So if you start the process and the first contract is approved even if you don't finish the process, will I only have to make the second transaction at the time I want to finish said deposit?

author: 0xcosme
content: Unless you modify the amount you previously approved

author: xerjos
content: Well, it failed for me and I was left hanging only in the first transaction and days later I revoked it out of fear, and it's simpler, no, I should have just continued with the process, right?

author: 0xcosme
content: You revoked an approval that you needed, it would be like an unnecessary waste of gas.

author: xerjos
content: Yes I know but it is the first time I tried it and since the process was not completed I thought the wallet was compromised

author: 0xcosme
content: Not necessarily, you have to look at the reason why the tx failed. If the wallet is compromised the result is the loss of your tokens, not a tx failure. Anyway, you were cautious, that's okay.

content: The case is that the first contract was approved well without errors, it gave an error but I didn't see the reason.

author: 0xcosme
content:
Hey! This seems to be related to the USDT Approval Situation. To troubleshoot this, check your wallet on https://revoke.cash by entering your wallet address in the search.

- Check the approvals tab for a USDT approval on the Aave pool, and revoke it.
- If you are unsure if a certain approval is for AAVE, you may revoke all USDT approvals.
- When you do the approval transaction in the AAVE UI, leave the amount as site-suggested.
- Do not tap the MAX button in MetaMask.

This will approve enough for you to withdraw/repay/supply.

author: ziga0840
content: If I understand how the price oracle works for LSTs my health factor can't be affected by market conditions/depegs when depositing weETH and borrowing ETH on scroll?

author: ziga0840
content: So a depeg in eETH/USD won't effect the position?

author: weed42069
content: Oracles use the exchange rate provided by the LST manager, rather than DEX rates

author: weed42069
content:
I E. Wsteth uses LIDO exhnage rate, weEth uses etherfi exchange rate

Depeg on dexes doesn't matter

author: ziga0840
content: So the only depeg that matters in that case is the stETH/ETH conversion rate provided by lido?

author: weed42069
content:
Correct! That is what is used to calculate the prices

There is a description on how they work here https://governance.aave.com/t/bgd-correlated-asset-price-oracle/16133 and a bit more technical on how they are capped here https://github.com/bgd-labs/aave-capo?tab=readme-ov-file#ratiocappriceadapter

author: hamiltonian026
content:
Please expand on the susde pool risk, is following scenario possible? I'm worried bc 1.3B$ of supply is not in proportion to on chain liquidity.

context: The susde-oracle is powered by a CAPO adapter +  usde chainlink  feed. Liquidation is at 92%,  fee is 3%. Most loans backed by the 1.3BB$ susde, are highly leveraged
1) After a few big usde redeems, the **ethena minting/redeem contract holds no more usdt **and doesn't get replenished for 5 minutes, during which:
2) **a whale dumps/fat fingers 40m usde,** with only 1% of slippage as most liquidity is in stablecoin-pools, but the price drops to 0.8usdc/usd. Or such amount is sold in short time for whatever other reason.
3) some bots instantly buy usde and wait for replenishment of the redeem contract, but **the price is still well below 0.92.** 
4)** the chainlink oracle updates, causing liquidation **on levered susde positions, say 100M$ susde. Let's say there is 30M$ of sub 3% slippage, on-chain susde->usde liquidity, so that's 30M$ worth of susde->usde->usdc flash-loan liquidations. 
Outside of this 3% slippage range of usde-susde there is no flashloan liquidation possible.  (maybe a few 10M$ of liquidations can be done by non-flashloans, eg the bot gets the susde and without selling, pays back the usdc from his balance, so no effect on price)
5) **all on chain stablecoin-liquidity **(bots and pools) that could restore price **gets used up by the cascade**
6) now the usde price and thus oracle price is toast, what now with** 900M$+ that can be liquidated at a big discount**?  One might consider it a â€œhighly profitable trading strategyâ€...

author: hammingster
content: What are the security implications of infinite approvals interacting with aave? e.g., supplying a token etc.

author: 0xcosme
content: Sorry for the inconvenience, we do not have more information than what we are providing.

author: 0xcosme
content: Hey! Infinite approvals on Aave allow the protocol unlimited access to your tokens, which poses risks if the contract is exploited or compromised. To reduce exposure, regularly revoke unused approvals, use limited allowances instead of infinite ones, and monitor transactions carefully.

author: jyames4667
content:
Hi guys, Iâ€™ve been holding eth for years now but interested in defi. I have a question and feel free to correct me if Iâ€™m wrong ðŸ˜‰ 

But if I put a big big chunk of my eth in AAVE and use their borrow feature, I can replace my credit card functionality?

author: weed42069
content:
Yup. This is how the etherfi cash card works actually.

Without an actual crypto card, one methods users conduct this is by using a real credit card to make normal purchases in real life, while borrowing stable coins every month to off ramp, and pay off their credit card.

This is effectively arbitraging the interest rates between DeFi and Tradfi while using your eth's price appreciation as a hedge against liquidations.

wsteth instead of eth also allows you have the built in LIDO yield working in your favor.

NFA, dyor

author: billy191
content:
Hi I am wondering about the liquidation, if health factor drop below < 1, so I won't get any different between supply and borrow right?

like I supply 33,503.25 USDT, I borrow 30.00 BNB (20,906.68 USD) Health factor 1.24, if liquidation, so what is my final balance? can someone help me?

I will be repaid only 15 BNB right?, and my USDT will only deduct for swapping 15 BNB at that price? and others USDT that I supply still remain?

author: 0xcosme
content: Hey! If your health factor drops below 1, part of your supplied collateral is sold to repay up to 50% of your debt, including a liquidation fee. In your case, a portion of your USDT collateral would be sold to cover that amount plus the fee. The rest of your USDT collateral would remain in your account, and the remaining 15 BNB debt would still need to be repaid to restore your health factor. To avoid liquidation, you can either repay part of your debt or add more collateral to improve your health factor.

author: darklord_gr
content: Isn't the utilization based on the available liquidity?

author: darklord_gr
content: If the utilization is more than 90% borrow rates increase

author: darklord_gr
content: So by increasing the liquidity collateral the utilization drops no?

author: albist
content:
Not exactly,
the utilization rate of the market does not take account for the Available Liquidity but for the Marklet Liquidity. You can display the Market Liquidity by clicking on "Edit properties".
The difference between Market Liquidity and Available Liquidity.
Market Liquidity: As you maybe already know, Morpho market are isolated. Market Liquidity is what is supplied in the market less what is borrowed.
Available Liquidity: to reagregate this isolated markets, there are reagragation layer on top. morpho Vaults on the supply side. And there is the [Public Allocator (with this explanatory video)](https://docs.morpho.org/public-allocator/overview) on the borrow side to reaggregate the liquidity. TL;DR of the Public allocator, it can retrieve liquidity from other markets right on time to allow borrowers to borrow more than the Market Liquidity. e.g Market Liquidity = 10, Borrower wants to borrow 20, if allowed by the parameters, the Public Allocator will retrieve 10 or more from other markets to allows the borrower to borrow more than what is actually in the market. This is why Available Liquidity > Market Liquidity
Let me know if not clear.

author: albist
content: The utilization rate takes account for the ratio between the loan asset supplied and the loan asset borrowed. The collateral is not taken into account.

author: darklord_gr
content: But my positions are so volatile that it's bad for the project

author: albist
content: Can you share on which market you have a position?

author: albist
content:
Depending on the liquidity of the market, high amount withdrawn can make the utilization rate increase, as well as the borrow interest rates. Such spikes are often quickly coming back to a more normal rate.
You can check directly the rate history in the market page on the Morpho interface: app.morpho.org
Use the search bard to find the market you are using on Contango ans you'll find more info.
e.g [sUSDe / USDT (LLTV=91.5%)](https://app.morpho.org/market?id=0xdc5333039bcf15f1237133f74d5806675d83d9cf19cfd4cfdd9be674842651bf&network=mainnet), you can see that there is a spike at the moment but the 1D or 7D average are around 14%

author: juanwittstatt.
content:
I have some questions regarding your explanation, specifically about this statement: "Available Liquidity: to reaggregate these isolated markets, there are reaggregation layers on top, Morpho Vaults on the supply side." and the example provided: "e.g. Market Liquidity = 10, Borrower wants to borrow 20, if allowed by the parameters, the Public Allocator will retrieve 10 or more from other markets to allow the borrower to borrow more than what is actually in the market."

Cross-Market Liquidity Sharing:
Does this mean that if there is insufficient liquidity in market 1, it will pull liquidity from market 2 (with the same tokens), and the total borrowed amount will be attributed to market 1? If this is correct, I would like to understand the incentives for market 2 to provide its supply to market 1, especially considering that both markets may have different parameters.

Role of Vaults in Liquidity Provision (In the context of your first statement about Vaults as a reaggregation layer):
How do Vaults interact in cases where additional liquidity is needed in a market?
The example provided seems to reference liquidity being pulled from other markets, not Vaults. Could you clarify the relationship between Vaults and liquidity reallocation across markets?

User Interaction with Markets:
What is the process for a regular user to invest in a Morpho market?
Do they have to supply liquidity exclusively through a Vault, or can they interact directly with an isolated market?

Do they have to supply liquidity exclusively through a Vault, or can they interact directly with an isolated market?

author: juanwittstatt.
content:
I have some questions regarding your explanation, specifically about this statement: "Available Liquidity: to reaggregate these isolated markets, there are reaggregation layers on top, Morpho Vaults on the supply side." and the example provided: "e.g. Market Liquidity = 10, Borrower wants to borrow 20, if allowed by the parameters, the Public Allocator will retrieve 10 or more from other markets to allow the borrower to borrow more than what is actually in the market."

Cross-Market Liquidity Sharing:
Does this mean that if there is insufficient liquidity in market 1, it will pull liquidity from market 2 (with the same tokens), and the total borrowed amount will be attributed to market 1? If this is correct, I would like to understand the incentives for market 2 to provide its supply to market 1, especially considering that both markets may have different parameters.

Role of Vaults in Liquidity Provision (In the context of your first statement about Vaults as a reaggregation layer):
How do Vaults interact in cases where additional liquidity is needed in a market?
The example provided seems to reference liquidity being pulled from other markets, not Vaults. Could you clarify the relationship between Vaults and liquidity reallocation across markets?

User Interaction with Markets:
What is the process for a regular user to invest in a Morpho market?
Do they have to supply liquidity exclusively through a Vault, or can they interact directly with an isolated market?

author: albist
content:
> Cross-Market Liquidity Sharing:
> Does this mean that if there is insufficient liquidity in market 1, it will pull liquidity from market 2 (with the same tokens), and the total borrowed amount will be attributed to market 1? If this is correct, I would like to understand the incentives for market 2 to provide its supply to market 1, especially considering that both markets may have different parameters.

On the borrow side yes, this is the purpose of the Public Allocator. You can read more about it in the documentation [here)(https://docs.morpho.org/public-allocator/overview).
There is no incentive 'for the market itself'. Incentive is for the borrowers to get in time liquidity.

author: albist
content:
> Cross-Market Liquidity Sharing:
> Does this mean that if there is insufficient liquidity in market 1, it will pull liquidity from market 2 (with the same tokens), and the total borrowed amount will be attributed to market 1? If this is correct, I would like to understand the incentives for market 2 to provide its supply to market 1, especially considering that both markets may have different parameters.

author: albist
content:
> Role of Vaults in Liquidity Provision (In the context of your first statement about Vaults as a reaggregation layer):
> How do Vaults interact in cases where additional liquidity is needed in a market?
> The example provided seems to reference liquidity being pulled from other markets, not Vaults. Could you clarify the relationship between Vaults and liquidity reallocation across markets?

Vaults curators can:
- manually reallocate between the markets they listed.
- enable the Public Allocator (see link in the answer above) with specific parameters.
Vaults curators allocate liquidity supplied to the Vault into the underlying markets. They can move this liquidity between markets to adapt their exposure with regard to their risk profile, to improve rates on markets (also optimizing Vault return), and to allow borrowers to borrow what they need.

author: juanwittstatt.
content:
Thank you @albist | Morpho ðŸ¦‹ , that makes sense now. I believe I understand better.

So in the example, the liquidity request from market 1 pulls supply from market 2. However, in practice, the entity providing the liquidity is actually the Vault (and not market 2). This happens because, if the benefit of keeping liquidity in market 2 is outweighed by the demand from market 1, the Vault will reallocate its supply accordingly.

If Iâ€™m understanding this correctly: Vaults can automatically reallocate liquidity to a specific market when requested, as the risk and parameters of the Vault are already predefined in the smart contract. This means that the additional supply available (when needed) will only come from Vaults that are compatible with market 1's parameters.

author: albist
content:
Basically the liquidity allocated by a vault in X markets can be reallocated between said markets if the Vault curators enabled the `Public Allocator (PA)` contract as `Allocator` of the Vault.
Then, the liquidity can be reallocated for borrowers purpose within a few constraints:
1. The curators set flow caps to determine how much can come in/out from a market
2. The Morpho interface has an algorithm that keep in check the PA. Purpose of this is if PA takes liquidity from market A to put it in market B because someone wants to borrow more than available in market B, algorithm will make sure that it doesn't take too much liquidity of the market A, because if it takes too much, utilization rate of market A will increase as well as borrow rate.

TL;DR
Curators enable PA and give it parameters. Goal of the PA is to allow on time liquidity for borrowers but without disturbing the market from which the liquidity is taken from.

author: juanwittstatt.
content:
Thank you, your previous response clarified a lot! I now have a few follow-up questions to better understand the details:

1. Who is responsible for managing the parameters of the Public Allocator (PA)? Is this handled directly by Morpho, or are Vault curators the ones who configure the PAâ€™s settings (like flow caps) within the smart contracts?

2. To what extent do Vault curators influence market parameters?

Do curators directly set parameters such as LLTV (Liquidation Loan-to-Value) or interest rates within a market, or are these parameters exclusively determined by the markets themselves?

3. Additionally, when it comes to Vaults, is the risk profile or criteria (e.g., LLTV thresholds) they will use for allocating liquidity publicly known in advance? Or is this something that becomes evident only once the allocation happens and liquidity is distributed across markets?

4. Why do some markets appear to be duplicated with identical performance, LLTV, and currency pairs? Is it possible for two markets to be exactly the same? Iâ€™ve noticed that sometimes the only difference is the oracle being used. What are the practical advantages or disadvantages of choosing a market based on the oracle alone? In what scenarios would a user prioritize one oracle over another for an otherwise identical market?

5. Are there any additional insights about the Grant programâ€™s focus? Do you know if there are specific areas of development or features Morpho is particularly interested in funding as part of the grants initiative?Â 

6. Do you have recommendations on the timing of Grant submissions? If we publish our proposal well ahead of the deadline, thereâ€™s a risk that someone might replicate or plagiarize the idea. Would you suggest submitting closer to the deadline to mitigate this risk, or is early submission encouraged for any specific reason?

author: albist
content:
hey,
1. Those are the curators who are enabling the Public Allocator (PA) for a specific Vault and setting the flow caps for the Vault's markets. 

2. A market have a few parameters chosen at creation (more on this [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/overview)). This parameters are immutable and can not be changed once the market is created. So Vault curators (and anyone else) can not influence markets' parameters. I would say than the main influence can have on markets is by managing the utilization rate of the market (the amount supplied over the amount borrowed) because it impacts the interest rate of the market.

3. When a market is created, you can check the several immutable parameters mentioned above. IThe market only appears on the interface once a Vault has listed it tho.

4. Two markets can no be exactly the same, at least one parameter is different. As you pointed out, in your case, the oracle is the parameter that differs. On the supply side it is up to the curator to choose a vault to list and allocate to according this parameters. On the borrow side indeed you may have to assess which oracle suits you best. Market choice is totally up to the user (there i an educational work to do on that front). Sometime the oracle nature is different 'secondary market' or 'exchange rate'. Sometimes it is just the oracle provider 'chainlink' or. 'redstone'.

5. 6. On the grant side I don't. know much more than what is presented in this [forum post](https://forum.morpho.org/t/call-for-grants/1177).

Let me know if additional info needed!

author: juanwittstatt.
content:
Thanks!

I need to understand the Public Allocator (PA) in more depth, and I want to confirm if Iâ€™ve understood it correctly. I see two possible interpretations:

1. Is the PA a smart contract that each Vault curator can adapt to their own criteria?
For example, if I am managing an ETH Vault, I set the PA as the allocator and define specific parameters or constraints under which my ETH can be moved. For instance: only to markets with a TVL greater than 80% and a specific token pair.

2. Alternatively, does enabling the PA mean the curator cannot define any custom parameters?
In this case, the PA would simply act autonomously, redistributing my ETH according to parameters pre-defined by Morpho to satisfy unmet borrowing demands across different markets.

Could you clarify which of these interpretations is correct?

content:
Thanks!
