Could you clarify which of these interpretations is correct?

author: juanwittstatt.
content:
Thanks!

I need to understand the Public Allocator (PA) in more depth, and I want to confirm if Iâ€™ve understood it correctly. I see two possible interpretations:

1. Is the PA a smart contract that each Vault curator can adapt to their own criteria?
For example, if I am managing an ETH Vault, I set the PA as the allocator and define specific parameters or constraints under which my ETH can be moved. For instance: only to markets with a TVL greater than 80% and a specific token pair.

2. Alternatively, does enabling the PA mean the curator cannot define any custom parameters?
In this case, the PA would simply act autonomously, redistributing my ETH according to parameters pre-defined by Morpho to satisfy unmet borrowing demands across different markets.

Could you clarify which of these interpretations is correct?

author: albist
content:
1. yes. A smart contract to which they give the allocator role in their vault. ([here](https://docs.morpho.org/public-allocator/overview) a reminder of the PA and [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho-vaults/concepts/roles) on on vaults' roles)
it is what you think except that the 'flow caps' that they set is market specific (e.g. market A can receive up to $10M and send up to $2M
when enabling the PA as allocator of their Vaults, the curators have to set specific flow caps (maxIn & maxOut)

1. is correct!

Did you take a look at [this section](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/tutorials/market-creation) to create a market? I think you can retrieve the same parameters than the existing market, only changing the collateral and loan asset address (and LLTV if you wish to).

Then to the [idToMarketParams function](https://sepolia.etherscan.io/address/0xd011EE229E7459ba1ddd22631eF7bF528d424A14#readContract#F4) and inputing the market ID: 0xe7647bb54063bd2143cc907edc7a9fadf560991bc70e781121ac96bfe60380c5

author: brianspha
content: How can I check if the max deposits has been reached

author: albist
content:
So confirmed, in a Vault you can only supply 1 asset. For a USDC vault, you can only supply USDC.
By default, there is no cap on a Vault. But curators can set cap to markets.
Let say Vault 1 set markets caps as below:
- Market A: 100M
- Market B: 100M
- Market C: 100M
The max deposit is 300M
Curators usually add an idle market with a large cap to virtually have no limit. Idle markets are markets where you can not borrow from and uses as some kind of "reserve" by curators to manage Vaults allocations.
Here is an example of the [Smokehouse USDT](https://app.morpho.org/vault?vault=0xA0804346780b4c2e3bE118ac957D1DB82F9d7484&network=mainnet) Vault where you can see the Supply cap on the Vault page:

author: tomrep
content: @Eden the oracle is wrongly configured here (good catch), the warning is here to protect you from using this market!

author: tomrep
content:
We have an oracle interface for this:
https://oracles.morpho.dev/oracle-decoder

And the dashboard is clearly displaying the error as well:


As oracle creation is permissionless, I think we can't prevent such misconfiguration, but we can educate and verify post creation.

For this the testor section is here to help/guide new oracle deployment!

content:
Hey,
By default, the Morpho API returns only the 100 first results and retrieve informations on the Ethereum network. You can refer to [the Paging, ordering and the filtering capabilities section](https://docs.morpho.org/apis/morpho/#paging-ordering-and-the-filtering-capabilities) for more info.

I'm integrating MetaMorpho vaults into our DeFi protocol and I have some questions about $MORPHO reward computations to know how these can be reflected easily to users. Should I ask my questions here directly ?

author: vblackwhale
content:
Yes I did and looked into the Universal Reward Distributor. If I understood correctly that makes it a bit trickier to integrate on-chain computation of those rewards on our side.
We have a contract that manages the user's deposits/withdraws to a specific vault. The contract can be either doing the deposit for the user or just receive the vault tokens directly from the user.
In this case, who is entitled to the rewards ? The account that is holding the vault tokens right ?

author: chadseam
albist
content:
Liquidity at the vault level is `sum(min(marketAllocation`, marketLiquidity)) for each markets.
For marketAllocation, you can maybe retrieve for a vault the list of markets via the supplyQueue or withdrawQueue function of a vault. Then for each market retrieve the position of the vault, but you would retrieve Vault shares that you would need to convert to asset.
Then you would need to retrieve Market liquidity for each of the market where the vault allocates.
It would allow you to make the calculation aboce.

author: albist
content: Correct, initial market parameters are immutable (more about this [here](https://docs.morpho.org/morpho/overview)).

author: eua0000
content:
NET APY weirdness:
While borrowed with %11, interface thinks that mine NET APY is %-19

author: eua0000
content: Probably, calculation made via Net worth... But I don't think if it's OK to calculate NET APY from net worth. It should be calculated from all deposits... So it cannot below -%11...

author: 0xcosme
content: Hey, the Net APY shows the overall impact of your supply and borrow positions on your net worth, including any incentives. To calculate it, multiply your deposits by their APYs, subtract your borrows multiplied by their APYs, and then divide that by your net worth. Itâ€™s not just the difference between supply and borrow APYsâ€”it gives you a clearer picture of how everything combined is affecting your returns or costs.

author: eua0000
content:
Yeah, as I guessed...
But IMO, It should be divided into "total deposits" instead of "net worth".
Otherwise it has no meaning and is misleading. Thanks.

author: weed42069
content:
There's nothing we can do about users signing malicious transactions.

There is a huge opsec issue when it comes to defi users, which is something that's discussed regularly amongst development teams.

As a protocol, we develop audited smart contracts that have not suffered any exploits.

Claiming that users funds are at all related to using the aave platform is a stretch, regardless if aTokens were stolen or not.

The bottom line is, in DeFi, there is an expectation that the user follows the same opsec as basic internet web-surfing

- don't visit malicious websites
- don't click links in DMs
- don't sign transaction you don't fully understand
- etc.

These ratings you referring to are likely angry users who signed a malicious transaction and blame aave. This is fine, it's not a reflection of aave, it's a reflection of the ignorance and refusal of accountability from users.

AAVE is the #1 platform in DeFi by tvl, it's safe to say institutions and users alike, trust aave more than they trust any other platform.

I'm sorry you fell victim to a scam, but take it as an expensive lesson on operational security. I remmeber we told you that a user in DMs was a scammer and you said something along the lines of "it wouldn't hurt to check it out anyway" - this is an example of extremely poor opsec, and there's nothing aave, as a protocol, can do to prevent you from doing this

author: mutedoodle
content:
I donâ€™t understand how they make money. They put an equal amount in eth longs and eths shorts, shouldnâ€™t that balance out then? @gite 
Is the arbitrage that much that it funds sUSDeâ€™s current apy of like 30%?

author: mutedoodle
content:
I donâ€™t understand how they make money. They put an equal amount in eth longs and eths shorts, shouldnâ€™t that balance out then? @gite 
Is the arbitrage that much that it funds sUSDeâ€™s current apy of like 30%?

author: chrissieboy_
content:
Simplified it works like this:
- You give Ethena ETH and receive USDe tokens
- Ethena stakes the ETH 
- Ethena takes a short position using perpetual ETH futures
- in a bull market the long position pay the shorts

You stake the USDe and reveive an APR from the ETH stake rewards and the funding rewards

author: mutedoodle
content: And in a bear market the short position will pay the long??

author: mutedoodle
content: But in the long run shouldnâ€™t the yield be 0 from shorting and longing a coin with equal amounts

author: tqt
content: no you can hold 1x spot and 1x short, so you don't pay anything for the long

author: chrissieboy_
content: The price exposure is 0 is you are both long and short (neutral strategy), the APR doesnt come from changes in the price, but from the staking of the long physical position plus the funding rate

author: defi_made_here
content: If sUSDe has a market price volatility, there are no risks for usdc lenders. If sUSDe has some backing losses, users will be liquidated. SUSDe has to lose more than 10% of its backing for fluid to encounter any bad debt

author: gitegite
content:
Hey so the question is slightly incomplete here
basically the gap only applies at the vault level 
so need to involve both Liquidity and Vault
Assume
-> total supply at liquidity layer 100, total borrowed out there 95. means 5 left
the gap applies on vault so
- case 1, vault is the only supplier at liquidity layer (only couple of these possible atm like weETHs vault): total supply vault = 100, so if gap is 5% any withdraw would revert.
- case2, vault supply is only a part of liquidity layer total supply, e.g. total supply vault = 40 (some other vault 40, fToken 20). if gap is 5% then withdrawable until total supply vault = 2

author: _theseer
content: can someone explain this to me? i have collateral earning 2.8% APR. im borrowing asset at 0.37 APR. no looping or anything like that, just a simple borrow. it says my APY is >6%. how can that be? i looked at APR to APY calculators and even compounding daily wouldn't explain that

author: _theseer
content: is it including points in the APY or something?

author: gitegite
content:
Hey the net APY is calculated as 
((Total supplied in USD* Supply APR) - (Total borrowed in USD * Borrow APR)) / (Total supplied in usd -total borrowed in usd)

author: justinmahone
content: Hi guys whats the architecture of the Fluid DEX? I lend collateral but instead of collateral in a single erc20 token, I can deposit collateral in a range (similar to univ3 LPs) between 2 tokens. Those "smart debt" collateral positions allow traders to utilize?

author: justinmahone
content: Hi guys whats the architecture of the Fluid DEX? I lend collateral but instead of collateral in a single erc20 token, I can deposit collateral in a range (similar to univ3 LPs) between 2 tokens. Those "smart debt" collateral positions allow traders to utilize?

author: justinmahone
content:
Im curious how the 39x LP works, to illustrate I will compare it to Aave since I know it well.

On Aave if I deposit ETH I get aETH in the protocol that gives me borrowing power, in E-Mode I could borrow 95% against it to loop. I take the ETH that I borrow lets say .90, deposit it again - now my collateral is 1.9ETH. Ofc i can borrow against this again and again, and the ETH is multiplied in the protocol and my collateral becomes large amounts of what it was previously.

In Fluid I can do the same thing but instead of ETH, I can deposit a concentrated Liquidity Position (lets say WstETH-wETH), and I borrow against it. Its the same case as above where now I have much more of the LP, but the LP I have doesnt actually multiply - its the same synthetic postion - that I keep borrowing? Or am I understanding this wrong

author: justinmahone
content:
another question - 
"Smart Debt allows the debt to be turned into a productive asset by using debt as trading liquidity, therefore earning trading fees that offset the cost of capital incurred by borrowing (APR). Smart debt can be considered as the inverse of any AMM pool.

Initial potential Smart Debts can be ETH/wstETH, ETH/weETH, USDC/USDT, etc. Governance can also explore trading-focused Smart Debt such as ETH<>USDC, ETH<>USDT, etc."

Lets take another example - I deposit ETH/wstETH as collateral. If I deposit this I earn fees on it since its used on the DEX. But If another user borrows this position, how does he also earn fees on it? How can the same LP be earning fees for both the lender/debtor=

author: smykjain
content:
Hey! Yes, the pools can have losses sometimes due to excessive rebalancings. While all other pools wstETH-ETH, weETH-ETH & USDC-USDT are running great. Recently, the rebalancing on WBTC-cbBTC pools were more than usual due to market volality.

We released 2 proposals to target these pain points to reduce rebalancings:
- Make range more wider: https://atlas.instadapp.io/proposals/59 (Will be executed in 27-28hrs)
- Reducing the cap of rebalancing from 0.5% to 0.3%: https://atlas.instadapp.io/proposals/61

To target rate spike on BTC market we released this, incentives on WBTC & cbBTC market to grow their market size: https://gov.instadapp.io/t/stage-1-fluid-to-2b-market-size/1001/2

All of these will be done within next 7 days.

author: tqt
content: No, It's because fUSDC is worth more than 1$ and it keeps accumulating the interest inside

author: tqt
content:
so let's say you deposited 500 USDC and get 485 fUSDC  so fUSDC is 500/485=1.0309...
as time goes on fUSDC will increase 1.031.. 1.032.. 1.04... cuz of interest

author: tqt
content: and you will still have 500 fUSDC but it will be 510 USDC for example

author: xcolo
content: Here is the problem in my eyes, In that day Fluid generated about 152m trading volume in less than 600 BTC in reserves. And most of the trades were one-sided which caused WBTC to depeg by about 0.5%. So this triggered the rebalance and resulted some loss in real (not IL).

author: xcolo
content: So the problem occurs when an asset depegs, and the algorithm performs a significant rebalance before the asset naturally returns to its peg. Making liquidity more deeper and the range more wider, also reducing rebalance can help this issue.

author: xcolo
content: Let's say if someone swaps 100 ETH for 390000 USDC on Fluid. The part 1 goes through SC, part 2 goes through SD. In SC, the number of ETH increases, the number of USDC decreases. Conversely, in SD, ETH debt reduces (repay), USDC debt increases (borrow). So from protocol side, the risk is hedged. That's my understandings.

author: xcolo
content: When there are liquidity in both SC and SD, the trade will go through SC and SD to get the best price. That's part 1,2

author: dknugo
content:
1. How to estimate the risk of liquidation? E.g. for manual Uni3 positions it's rather easy to calculate LP price depending on the price of underlying tokens, so I can make simulation in Excel and find out at what price my LP collateral will be liquidated (e.g. on Stella or Tarot). But on Fluid it's more complicated: your collateral and debt are auto-rebalanced, ratio of assets in SC & SD are inverse, etc. Simulation is especially important for volatile vaults like ETH/USDC because the risk of liquidation is higher
2. How to estimate the losses due to rebalancing? E.g. I provided liquidity into cbBTC/WBTC vault. But my equity is gradually decreasing in spite of positive NET APR advertized in UI. Yes, I've seen explanations from Samyak on gov forum regarding cbBTC/WBTC vault we all know that rebalancing losses take place in all DEX vaults. So end users need some tools to estimate these potential losses. Otherwise liquidity provision turns into a gamble. Maybe in this case we need some backtests on historical data + compare backtest results with actual performance

author: schizoxbt
content: General msg for everyone: stay safe and vigilant regarding funds. Any emails claiming to be about liquidations for on-chain protocols are scams. We will never email you, neither will any protocol that you haven't given an email too (and even then). Scammers try to prey on you at your most vulnerable, ie down periods in markets and near holidays. Be careful!

author: defi_made_here
content:
Imagine you have a normal usdt-usdc dex lp on uniswap. What happens when usdc depegs? Everyone is selling usdc for usdt so you, as an lp, buying usdc for usdt.

Same here, traders will be selling usdc and buying usdt. Traders will be repaying your usdc debt and borrowing more usdt on your behalf. Your usdc debt will be increasing if usdc depegs

author: defi_made_here

author: defi_made_here
content:
There is no public roadmap, the protocol is governed by the token holders and anyone can offer changes to the protocol. Of course, the team is the core contributor as of now and we are growing the protocol as we think is the best way to scale.

There is a short term roadmap (weeks-months) that includes adding more assets to fluid lending and dex, growing fluid on L2s, etc

And long term roadmap which changes as per the prevailing market conditions. For example, we were planning to launch uncollateralized borrowing protocol but then changed the plans because it does not offer the best growth for fluid atm. It will only increase the borrowing demand which we have a lot but it will not increase the lending on fluid which is the main goal as of now.

We will put a lot of affords into dex v2 as we see that the dex can be very very profitable and dex valuations are much higher than lending market valuations. We will make some announcements in the coming weeks about dex v2

We are also exploring some more protocols on top of fluid. One of them, not a big one, might be launched in February. The other one is big one and is in the stage of evaluating the business opportunity.

author: defi_made_here
content: For the wider market, we prioritize safety over fast and (in our opinion) unsustainable growth. 10% of the assets are making 90% of the market, and the rest 90% of the assets correspond to the remaining 10% of the market. Lenders and borrowers are much safer on fluid if they are only exposed to the blue chip assets

author: crazysonofagun
content:
Even now one of the main concerns I'm seeing is how Impermanent Loss issue is addressed in the ETH-USDC pool. Given that we're basically talking about leveraged concentrated liquidity, it can bring the Impermanent Loss to a much higher degree in highly volatile markets (depending on the collateral and debt chosen ofc) 
It's nice to see the traction in terms of volume, but would also be nice to see what's the extracted value that is emerging from capturing this market share

author: defi_made_here
content:
So il is the same as it would be in uniswap pool of the same range

The issue here is that 

1) we capture less fees than we have to so LPs get less trading apr that has to cover IL (will improve as more traders use Fluid)

2) LPs can not select their own ranges (will be addressed in dex v2)

author: crazysonofagun
content: But doesn't using leverage in the liquidity pools inherently imply higher risk for the LPers than it would be on Uniswap?

author: defi_made_here
content: If you generate $10m liquidity with $1m TVL, you will get the same fees and il as if you provided $10m TVL on uni.

author: crazysonofagun
content: In absolute terms â€” 100% I agree, but in relative terms the impact on 10x leveraged provided liquidity carries 10x IL, or am I missing something

author: crazysonofagun
content: that's what i'm saying, would love to see the comparative performance of realized fees vs realized IL

author: stephenwong3524
content: When user A transfers a certain amount of aTokens to user B, how many corresponding tokens will user B receive when withdrawing from the Aave platform? How is this exchange rate calculated?

author: stephenwong3524
content: If user A supplies n tokens, they will receive n aTokens. How does Aave know how many tokens user B should withdraw?

author: stephenwong3524
content:
In previous models, such as Spark, depositing DAI would return sDAI, and there was a slowly increasing exchange rate between sDAI and DAI. When returning the same amount of sDAI, one could obtain more DAI.

However, in Aave V3, if you deposit \( n \) DAI, you receive \( n \) aDAI in a 1:1 ratio, while also recording the liquidity index at the time of supply. When you return \( n \) aDAI, the current liquidity index is compared with the liquidity index at the time of deposit to calculate how much DAI should be returned. 

Now, the questions arise:

1. If I deposit DAI twice, will Aave record the amount I deposited each time along with the liquidity index at that time?
2. If I transfer my aDAI to someone else, can that person still earn the yield from the time between the supply and the withdrawal when they withdraw from Aave? If so, how does Aave achieve this?

author: stephenwong3524
content:
In previous models, such as Spark, depositing DAI would return sDAI, and there was a slowly increasing exchange rate between sDAI and DAI. When returning the same amount of sDAI, one could obtain more DAI.

However, in Aave V3, if you deposit \( n \) DAI, you receive \( n \) aDAI in a 1:1 ratio, while also recording the liquidity index at the time of supply. When you return \( n \) aDAI, the current liquidity index is compared with the liquidity index at the time of deposit to calculate how much DAI should be returned. 

Now, the questions arise:

1. If I deposit DAI twice, will Aave record the amount I deposited each time along with the liquidity index at that time?
2. If I transfer my aDAI to someone else, can that person still earn the yield from the time between the supply and the withdrawal when they withdraw from Aave? If so, how does Aave achieve this?

author: defispartan
content:
currentBalance = scaledBalance * liquidityIndex

Whenever an account performs an action involving aTokens (such as transferring or re-supplying), the aTokens that have been accumulated are minted and a new checkpoint for the scaledBalance and liquidityIndex are created

This logic is in the [ScaledBalanceTokenBase contract](https://github.com/aave-dao/aave-v3-origin/blob/be37b99b8fd47b5087e918bb2d4726d6470ab5c5/src/contracts/protocol/tokenization/base/ScaledBalanceTokenBase.sol#L55)

author: rajputanuj
content:
I am trying to build a system on Aave v2 where I can calculate how much `aUSDC (aTokens)` I will receive for a given amount of `USDC (Token)`. I am using the following formula:
`aToken_amount = (token_amount * 10**27 + (liquidityIndex / 2)) // liquidityIndex`
However, when I retrieve the `liquidityIndex` for USDC using the `getReserveData` function of the `LendingPool contract`, I get the value `1181606764854759047178985748`. Using this value, I am unable to compute the correct exchange rates. For example using this liquidity index i got `85 aUSDC` in return of `100 USDC` but on `Aave app` its showing `100:100(approx)`

Can someone help me identify what I might be doing wrong?

author: defispartan
content:
Supplying 100 USDC receives 100 aUSDC

The balance of aTokens update with accrued interest based on the following formula:

`currentATokenBalance = scaledATokenBalance * liquidityIndex`

- `scaledBalance` is calculated and stored for each account, updates each time the account interacts with `Pool` 
- `liquidityIndex` is shared by all suppliers and increases continuously

author: nocibambi
content:
Hi, I created a point tracker to evaluate aave depositor engagement: https://github.com/nocibambi/aave-lp-point-tracker

Let me know if you find this interesting or if you have feedback or questions regarding its logic. Would be happy to discuss.

Functional summary:
> An off-chain points tracker for liquidity providers on-chain. Tracks all TVL, in USD over time held by each depositor on Aave for the month of September (1st - 30th inclusive). Presents the numbers in an API. Each USD worth of TVL (any asset) held for 1 day counts as 1 point for the respective user.
> 
> Current implementation works with Aave V3 on the Ethereum mainnet.

supply rate = liquidityRate
borrow rate = variableBorrowRate

author: defispartan
content:
This error means that the CREATE2 factory address that is provided in the linked utility contract is not deployed to the current chain, you would either need to find an existing address of the factory or manually deploy on the chain

https://github.com/aave-dao/aave-v3-origin/blob/9a6add741c8024c49186a08aca14192f6268be50/src/deployments/contracts/utilities/Create2Utils.sol#L10

author: defispartan
content:
This error code is thrown when specific collateral conditions are not met: https://github.com/aave/protocol-v2/blob/ce53c4a8c8620125063168620eba0a8a92854eb8/contracts/protocol/libraries/logic/ValidationLogic.sol#L202

This require statement is kind of difficult to understand so here's the summary from ChatGPT:

The error is thrown if none of the following conditions are true:

    - The user is not using the asset as collateral.
        If the user is using the asset as collateral, the error is thrown.

    - The asset has an LTV (loan-to-value) of 0.
        If the asset does not have LTV set to 0, the error is thrown.

    - The user is trying to borrow an amount that is greater than their balance of aToken for that asset.
        If the user tries to borrow an amount less than or equal to their balance, the error is thrown.

author: defispartan
content: As long as the borrow position is not liquidated, it's up to the user to decide when to repay

author: andell_
content:
Hey, I am a bit confused on the credit delegations.
As i understand it you can delegate credit for users to only borrow a specific token, are there any contracts built ontop that allows a delegate credit in terms of "dollars" or similar such that i can credit a contract such that it can borrow up to a total of $X of any of the collateral types.

author: defispartan
content:
The health factor remaining after withdraw must be > 1

The formula for health factor is:

```
Health Factor = (Total Collateral Value * Weighted Average Liquidation Threshold) / Total Borrow Value
```

so:

```
Max Withdrawal Amount = Total Collateral Value âˆ’ (Total Borrow Value / Weighted Average Liquidation Thresholdâ€‹)
```

author: defispartan
content:
You're correct that [credit delegation](https://aave.com/docs/developers/credit-delegation) works by delegating in a specific debtToken

I'm not aware of a smart contract that would enable this functionality you're mentioning

One potential way that it could be implemented is for the delegator to transfer the collateral (aTokens) to an intermediate contract, and that contract manages delegations with custom logic

author: defispartan
content:
Utilization rate = total borrowed / total supplied

The total borrowed (`totalVariableDebt`) and total supplied (`totalLiquidty`) can be queried onchain and formatted using the [Aave Utilities SDK](https://github.com/aave/aave-utilities)

author: defispartan
content:
If the code size limit is exceeded then you could try decreasing the number of optimizer runs

You may also want to check if there is a size limitation of the network you're deploying on, the compiler options in aave-dao repo are assuming a max code size of 24kb (Ethereum default)

author: defispartan
content:
You can get the balance of individual borrow positions by querying `balanceOf(userAddress)` on the corresponding debt token contract

You can find the address of each debt token contract in the [Aave Docs](https://aave.com/docs/resources/addresses (under the reservers tab) or in the [BGD Address Book](https://github.com/bgd-labs/aave-address-book)

author: defispartan
content:
You can query all supply and borrow balances for an address with the [UiPoolDataProvider](https://aave.com/docs/developers/smart-contracts/view-contracts) view contract

You can find the UiPoolDataProvider address for each market in the [Aave Docs](https://aave.com/docs/resources/addresses) or [BGD Address Book](https://bgd-labs/aave-address-book)

There is also an [SDK](https://github.com/aave/aave-utilities) available to query and format data from this contract

author: defispartan
content:
The [credit delegation allowance](https://sepolia.arbiscan.io/address/0x486c2d3f59e4d72f3caa301a7ef19e3db657f5b0#readContract#F9 ) for parameters (`fromUser` = 0xf2873f92324e8ec98a82c47afa0e728bd8e41665 `toUser` = 0x20040a64612555042335926d72b4e5f667a67fa1) returns `100000000000`

This is less than the amount being borrowed in the transaction (`30000000000000000`) which is where the underflow error occurs

author: defispartan
content:
`accruedInterest = AToken.balanceOf(address) - (AToken.scaledBalanceOf(address) * AToken.getPreviousIndex(address))`

If you are using the initial amount supplied instead of `AToken.scaledBalanceOf(address)` in your calculation then this would cause the calculation to be lower than the actual accrued interest / amount available to withdraw

author: defispartan
content: All amounts in reserve data are returned with `decimals` of the underlying token (e.g. USDC on ETH mainnet has 6 decimals so 1000000 = 1 USDC)

author: defispartan
content: Each Aave Market has an `AaveOracle` contract which is a registry of the oracles for all reserve tokens. You can find the address of this contract using [these sources](https://discord.com/channels/602826299974877205/636902500041228309/1315811427927199805)

author: defispartan
content:
There are two ways that you could approach this:

1. Query contracts (Atoken.balanceOf) at previous block using archive node
2. Calculate balance based on most recent event update from indexed data source such as TheGraph (here is an [example](https://github.com/aave/interface/pull/2288/files) of querying / formatting for a similar use case)

author: defispartan
content: Thanks for reporting, responded to the issue on GitHub

author: defispartan
content:
You can see the individual markets registered under the [Events](https://etherscan.io/address/0xbaA999AC55EAce41CcAE355c77809e68Bb345170#events) tab

Since the markets were initialized within a governance payload, the transactions were executed inside of another contract call and don't show up directly under the "Transactions" tab

author: defispartan
content:
`poolAddressesProvider.getPool()` will always return the pool address, and the address of individual underlying tokens will not change

Approvals are always executed on the underlying token. In the case of native tokens such as ETH, the asset that must be approved and supplied to the pool is the wrapped variant: WETH

author: defispartan
content:
Aave V2 and V3 only operate with ERC-20 tokens, so to perform an action with a native token (ETH) it must be wrapped into an ERC-20 (WETH)

The [WrappedTokenGateway](https://aave.com/docs/developers/smart-contracts/wrapped-token-gateway) is a contract that performs the wrap/unwrap operations internally, allowing users to convert between native and wrapped tokens when interacting with Aave

author: defispartan
content:
All borrow transactions occur and accumulate with the wrapped token (WETH)

If a user selects the option to borrow in native token (ETH), it uses [this function}(https://aave.com/docs/developers/smart-contracts/wrapped-token-gateway#write-methods-borroweth) to borrow WETH -> unwrap to ETH in the same transaction

author: defispartan
content: There isn't a feature for this on app.aave.com, but there are other apps such as Instadapp and DeFiSaver that do

author: defispartan
content:
You could either:
- Create a fork network and perform a simulation of the `Pool.supply` -> query rates with  `Pool.getReserveData` (using tools such as Tenderly)
- Manually calculate by implementing the logic of [calculateInterestRates](https://github.com/aave-dao/aave-v3-origin/blob/1dab6e5b46cd1a8900a79fbcedce87f0d751a0a8/src/contracts/misc/DefaultReserveInterestRateStrategyV2.sol#L125), with the value of `availableLiquidity`  updated based on the amount you want to supply

author: branzinho
content:
Is `currentLiquidationThreshold` used to calculate `healthFactor` in the user account?
```function getUserAccountData(address user) external view virtual override returns (
    uint256 totalCollateralBase,
    uint256 totalDebtBase,
    uint256 availableBorrowsBase,
    uint256 currentLiquidationThreshold,
    uint256 ltv,
    uint256 healthFactor
)```

Is that the same liquidation threshold used here
```Health Factor = (Total Collateral Value * Weighted Average Liquidation Threshold) / Total Borrow Value```
https://aave.com/docs/concepts/liquidations#undefined-liquidations

author: branzinho
content: is there a reason why one is called current liquidation threshold, while the other one is weighted average liquidation threshold

author: branzinho
content: `currentLiquidationThreshold` in `UserAccountData` doesn't seem to apply to a specific asset, but rather the user account as a whole

author: defispartan
content:
You can find the Pool address for all markets here: https://github.com/bgd-labs/aave-address-book/tree/main/src

Tokens can only be withdrawn by calling `Pool.withdraw`  if there is sufficient liquidity of the underlying token (i.e. the aToken contract must have a balance of the underlying token)

author: defispartan
content:
Each [reserve](https://aave.com/docs/primitives/reserve) has an individual `liquidationThreshold` parameter

The `currentLiquidationTreshold` value returned from `Pool.getUserAccountData` is the average of the reserve parameters weighted by the account's balance of each reserve
